                      THE CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC
           ECONOMIC MANAGEMENT AND GOVERNANCE REFORM GRANT


                       GRANT AND PROGRAM SUMMARY




Recipient            Central African Republic
Implementing Agency  Ministry of Planning, Economics and International Cooperation
Amount               SDR 4.8 million (US$7.9 million equivalent)
Terms                Grant
Tranching            One tranche
Description          A one tranche development policy operation, the Economic Management and
                     Governance Reform Grant (EMGRG) supports the implementation of the
                     CAR's Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper. The proposed grant focuses on two
                     main policy areas: (i) strengthening public finance management; and (ii)
                     improving public sector and economic governance. This operation directly
                     supports two pillars of the PRSP: (i) promoting good governance and the rule
                     of law (pillar 2); and (ii) rebuilding and diversifying the economy (pillar 3). In
                     addition, it will assist the Government in attaining some of the HIPC
                     Completion Point triggers and will provide much needed external resources to
                     ensure timely payment of public sector salaries and external debt service.
Benefits             Reforms supported by EMGRG will contribute to improve the efficiency and
                     transparency of government operations and improve public sector and
                     economic governance. In particular it is expected to: (i) establish more
                     transparent accounting system and timely and reliable budget reporting; (ii)
                     improve domestic revenue mobilization capacity; (iii) improve the visibility of
                     government's governance efforts; and (iv) set the stage for a competitive
                     environment in the forestry and the downstream oil sector.
Risks                The EMGRG has significant security, political, sustainability,
                     macroeconomic, and institutional capacity risks. This reflects the country's
                     fragile security and political situation, the risks associated with low
                     government revenue, and weak financial controls. As in many conflict affected
                     countries, deterioration in the security situation constitutes an important source
                     of risk for the operation. Likewise, a reversal in the political stabilization
                     process, together with a weakening of ownership over the key measures
                     agreed with the Government, could undermine the development objectives of
                     the operation. To mitigate these risks, the Government has expressed
                     ownership and has demonstrated a real commitment to reforms through the
                     prior actions already carried out to start implementing its reforms program,
                     and the definition of the follow on measures targeting critical areas of
                     economic management and governance. To reduce the risk of weak
                     institutional capacity, the operation focuses on sustaining government reforms
                     that have started generating positive results and on a limited number of reform
                     areas. Although this operation is designed as a one-year-stand-alone budget
                     support, possible follow-up measures have been identified taking into
                     consideration the need for continuity in the reform program.
Operation ID Number  P106458



                                            iii


  INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT ASSOCIATION PROGRAM
        DOCUMENT FOR AN ECONOMIC MANAGEMENT AND
                       GOVERNANCE REFORM GRANT
                  TO THE CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC



                        I.   INTRODUCTION AND OVERVIEW

1.         This Program Document presents a proposed Economic Management and
Governance Reform Grant (EMGRG) for the Central African Republic (CAR) in
the amount of SDR 4.8 million (US$7.9 million equivalent). This is the second
Development Policy Operation (DPO) aimed at supporting the Government of the CAR,
after its successful reengagement with the donor community in 2006. The proposed Grant
will be a one-tranche operation supporting the 2008 budget.

2.         The operation supports the implementation of the country's PRSP. The full
PRSP describes the government's comprehensive strategy for accelerating economic
growth and reducing poverty for 2008-2010. The PRSP shares the broad goals and
pillars of the interim strategy for 2006-2008: (i) restoring security and consolidating
peace; (ii) promoting good governance and the rule of law; (iii) rebuilding and
diversifying the economy; and (iv) developing human capital. It was adopted by the
Government in June 2007 and presented to the donor community and civil society in
September 2007.

3.         The proposed Grant would support the second and third pillars of the
PRSP. The economic reform program aims to further strengthen budget reporting and
public sector and economic governance. The fiscal effort will be supported by policies
aimed at improving the accounting system and budget execution reporting and
government's revenue mobilization capacity as well as treasury control over government
resources. Structural reforms directed at rebuilding the economy aim to: (i) strengthen
governance and anti-corruption efforts; and (ii) establish a legal and regulatory
framework conducive to the development of a competitive oil and environmentally
sustainable forestry sector.

4.         The Grant is aligned with the objectives of the Joint Interim Strategy Note
(JISN), which outlines support by the World Bank and the African Development
Bank (AfDB) for an 18 month period, covering FY07-08. The JISN supports the
Government in its efforts to spur economic recovery and help strengthen public sector
governance spanning public finance management, both from the expenditure and revenue
perspectives; economic governance in key sectors such as management of natural
resources; public administration; and public sector governance.

5.         Proceeds of the proposed Grant would also provide continued support to
consolidate the reforms initiated by the Government with the support of the previous
operation the "Reengagement and Institution Building Support Program Grant"
(RIBSUP; FY07). Implementation over the course of RIBSUP has supported progress in


                                            1

a number of priority reform areas. These include: (i) the strengthening of Treasury
operations; (ii) the adoption of a unified payroll management system for civil and
military personnel; (iii) improving tax and customs administration; (iv) redressing state-
owned utility companies performance; (v) strengthening the state's capacity to fight
corruption; and (vi) enhancing transparency and improved legal and regulatory
framework to strengthen the credibility of the State, in particular with regard to natural
resources and telecommunications.

6.       The proposed Grant is part of an overall package of World Bank support
which has as its objective: (i) deepening public financial management reforms; (ii)
strengthening the government's governance efforts aimed at enhancing transparency and
accountability in the public sector, forestry and oil sector. In addition, it will assist the
Government in attaining some of the HIPC Completion Point triggers and will provide
much needed external resources to ensure timely payment of public sector salaries and
external debt service. In particular, it is supported by components of a US$6.8 million
grant from the Low Income Countries Under Stress (LICUS) Trust Fund, approved in
October 2006, to provide, among other areas, capacity-building and technical assistance
to enhance governance and economic management systems (EGEMAS). A planned new
LICUS grant (FY08), would provide continued support to public finance management
and governance in key sectors, including the oil sector. It will complement donors'
support for CAR's program, in particular the efforts of the IMF, the European
Commission (EC) and other bilateral partners.

7.       The     EMGRG        has    significant    security,  political,    sustainability,
macroeconomic, and institutional capacity risks. This reflects the country's fragile
security and political situation, the risks associated with low government revenue, and
weak financial controls. As in many conflict affected countries, deterioration in the
security situation constitutes an important source of risk for the operation. Likewise, a
reversal in the political stabilization process, together with a weakening of ownership
over the key measures agreed with the Government, could undermine the development
objectives of the operation. To mitigate these risks, the Government has expressed
ownership and has demonstrated a real commitment to reforms through the prior actions
already carried out to start implementing its reforms program, and the definition of the
follow on measures targeting critical areas of economic management and governance. To
reduce the risk of weak institutional capacity, the operation focuses on sustaining
government reforms that have started generating positive results and on a limited number
of reform areas. Although this operation is designed as a one-year-stand-alone budget
support, possible follow-up measures have been identified taking into consideration the
need for continuity in the reform program.


              II. COUNTRY CONTEXT AND THE GOVERNMENT
                                             PROGRAM


8.       CAR has experienced sustained periods of political instability and internal
conflict, resulting in weak governance and poor socio-economic outcomes. This



                                              2

instability, particularly since 1980, has significantly eroded the country's infrastructure
and private sector, resulting in steadily declining living standards. It is estimated that the
contraction of activities since the mid-1990s led to the disappearance of two-thirds of
formal sector enterprises and a collapse of agricultural exports. Real GDP per capita fell
from US$495 in 1990 to under US$300 over 1994-2002, but since 2004 the economy has
started a period of modest recovery, with real per capita income rising to an estimated
US$386 in 2007, although this partly reflects the falling value of the US dollar vis-à-vis
the euro and the CFA franc.1 Average annual real GDP rose on average by a mere 0.6
percent between 2002 and 2007, reflecting a steep fall in real GDP of 7.6 percent in 2003.
However, economic growth has accelerated since 2006, with real growth of 4 percent in
2006, and 4.2 percent in 2007. According to household survey data, 67.2 percent of the
population lived below the poverty line in 2003, with poverty particularly widespread in
rural areas, at 71.7 percent.

                         A. POLITICAL AND SECURITY DEVELOPMENTS

9.          The holding of multiparty elections in 1993 was followed by a decade of
ethnic instability and political tension, with army mutinies in 1996-1997 and a failed
military coup in 2001. In 2003, a military insurgency headed by General François
Bozizé came to power and established a transitional Government. Subsequently, the
Government organized a political process including (i) the organization of a national
dialogue in September 2003, bringing together all the political parties and civil society
organizations; (ii) the adoption via a referendum of a constitution in December 2004; and
(iii) the holding of legislative and presidential elections in March and May 2005.

10.         Mr. Bozizé was elected president after a run-off contest and a new
Government was formed in July 2005. These successful elections provided an
opportunity for the Government to initiate security sector reforms. However, the
implementation of the roadmap for sustained reconciliation and the strengthening of the
democratization process are constrained by limited resources. The CAR still lacks
defense and security forces capable of ensuring security within the country, largely
reflecting an ageing army and a shortage of financial resources in the face of large needs.

11.         Despite a general improvement of the security situation and political
stability, the current security situation remains precarious. Banditry remains an
important concern in certain rural regions, particularly the Bangui-Cameroon corridor.
The Government is faced with an armed rebellion, based in the northern part of the
country and with rear bases in neighboring countries, seeking to destabilize the country.
Acts of violence have been reported in a recent Human Rights Watch report which
documented significant abuses (including forced displacement and extra-judicial
killings), particularly in the northern part of the country.




1A large part of the rise in real GDP per capita in 2002-2006 reflects exchange rate fluctuations between
the CFAF franc, which is tied to the euro, and the US dollar. Thus, in local currency, CAR's per capita in
2006 was CFAF 186,003, which was lower than in 2002, when it was CFAF 187,798. It is only in 2007 that
per capita, at CFAF 194,459, exceeded the level of five years earlier.



                                                     3

12.       In addition to rebel activity in the northwest, security in the northeast of
the country has also been undermined by spillovers of the conflict in Darfur and
Chad. The regional environment remains marked by conflict --the Democratic Republic
of Congo, Chad, and Darfur in Sudan--and aggravates the difficulties encountered by the
defense and security forces. It is estimated that some 291,000 people in CAR have fled
from their homes because of violence, 212,000 of who are internally displaced, while an
estimated 79,000 have crossed borders into Chad, Cameroon, and Sudan. An additional
flow of refugees to the CAR are people escaping violence in Sudan's South Darfur
region. The recent UN decision to deploy a peacekeeping force in the Darfur region of
Sudan and in the border area with Chad should help improve the overall security
situation.

13.       The CAR has explicitly requested support for security reforms and has
embarked on a series of initiatives in the security sector aided by donors. Efforts to
restore security are supported by the United Nations Office for Consolidation of the
Peace in Central Africa (BONUCA), France, and the regional forces, Forces
Multinationale de la CEMAC (FOMUC), composed of forces from CEMAC member
countries, that are financed by the EC. Since 2001, BONUCA has been supporting the
government's efforts to consolidate peace and national reconciliation, strengthen
democratic institutions and facilitate the international political support for national
reconstruction and economic recovery. BONUCA has also focused on reinforcing
cooperation between the UN and CEMAC with a view to facilitating and strengthening
initiatives aimed at addressing trans-border insecurity. With French assistance the
Government has prepared a white paper on the restructuring, training, and equipping of
defense forces. UNDP has provided support for the fight against the proliferation of small
arms and co-financed the demobilization and reintegration of former combatants. In
addition, the Government has signed peace accords with the UFDR and FDPC rebel
movements in 2007, and it has committed itself to undertaking a political round table to
reinforce dialogue between the opposition and the ruling party.

                      B. RECENT MACROECONOMIC PERFORMANCE


14.       Economic performance has been uneven over the past decade, with widely
fluctuating annual changes to economic output (Figures 1-2). Since the political
transition in March 2003, economic recovery has been gaining momentum, with real
GDP growth rising from 1 percent in 2004 to 4 percent in 2006 and an estimated 4.2
percent in 2007. Real GDP per capita, which averaged minus 1.2 percent over 2003-
2007, did see positive growth rates since 2005. In terms of sectoral economic growth, the
economic recovery since 2004 has been driven by developments in the mining and
forestry sectors. The contribution of the primary sector has been uneven and variable. In
2006 it is estimated that the primary sector represented 57 percent of economic output,
with the secondary sector accounting for 16 percent, and the remainder being the tertiary
sector. Only in 2006 was the contribution of the primary sector significant and positive,
contributing by 2.7 percentage points to overall growth.




                                             4

15.      Since mid-2005, the CAR has made significant progress in strengthening
macroeconomic stability and has implemented macroeconomic and structural policies
under the IMF's PRGF-supported program approved in December 2006 that have
generally been satisfactory.2 The second review of the program is expected to be
considered by the IMF's Executive Board in June 2008 (see Annex 7). Inflation has
remained low, averaging 2.5 percent, in part reflecting the regional monetary
arrangements and monetary policy of the regional central bank BEAC. Annual average
inflation rose to 6.7 percent in 2006, reflecting an adjustment of petroleum prices, an
increase in indirect taxes, and higher food prices due to the level of instability in the
countryside. However, inflation fell significantly in 2007, to an estimated 0.9 percent.
Despite strong export growth and a significant rise in official transfers, the current-
account deficit in 2007 rose to 4.4 percent of GDP, up from 2.7 percent of GDP in 2006.
As timber and diamonds account for 85 percent of exports, developments in these two
products largely determine export performance.3

16.      Public expenditure remains low by Sub-Saharan African standards, at 11.8
percent of GDP in 2007, and is insufficient to meet the CAR's needs for human and
physical investments. Public expenditure declined in 2007, with the brunt of adjustment
falling on capital expenditure, which declined to CFAF 29.4 billion in 2007, down from
CFAF 37.7 billion in 2006, reflecting lower external financing. Investment has averaged
7.7 percent of GDP in 2003-07. In particular, private investment is low, averaging 4.9
percent of GDP in 2003-07, and is low, even by Sub Saharan Africa standards, although
it has been rising in the last two years, reaching 6.2 percent of GDP in 2007. Public
expenditure is constrained by low domestic revenue mobilization and limited donor
support. Over recent years, the government's fiscal objectives have been achieved


2 In December 2006 the CAR's PRGF was approved by the IMF for an amount equivalent to about
US$56.4 million to support the Government's economic program into 2009.
3Wood product exports account for nearly half of merchandise exports.



                                                   5

through tight control over expenditures, which is necessary to mitigate the impact of the
unpredictability of programmed aid inflows. These outcomes emphasize the need for
enhancing efforts to mobilize domestic revenue and improve modalities of aid delivery.
Realistically, room for fiscal space will continue to remain small without a significant
increase in external assistance.

17.       Tax revenue is among the lowest in Sub-Saharan Africa, at a mere 7.3
percent of GDP in 2007. As a percentage of GDP, tax revenue has increased only
modestly over 2004-07, rising by a mere 0.1 percentage points over this period and
falling over 2006-07. Low levels of tax revenue make it difficult for the Government to
gain fiscal maneuvering space.

18.       Total revenue fluctuates considerably from year to year depending on
grant disbursements made by the donor community (Figure 3). Although total
revenue as a percentage of GDP averaged 14.1 percent in 2003-07, this average hides
significant fluctuations. In 2006, total revenue rose to 22.8 percent of GDP, up from 12.3
percent in 2005, before falling to an estimated 14.3 percent in 2007. The large rise in total
revenue in 2006 is to a large extent attributable to multilateral budget support intended to
provide financing for the Government to repay outstanding multilateral arrears.

19.       Following the reengagement with the donor community, the CAR has
arguably broken the vicious circle of poor fiscal performance and has posted fiscal
surpluses as a result of external assistance. The fiscal surplus (including grants)
amounted to 9 percent of GDP in 2006 and 1.6 percent of GDP in 2007; excluding grants
the CAR posted fiscal deficits of 4.4 percent of GDP and 5.5 of GDP percent over the
same period. The Government has made considerable efforts to repay arrears in 2006-07.
The repayment of large outstanding arrears to multilateral donors, which was essential for
reengagement with the donor community, and the repayment of a fraction of domestic
arrears, led to an overall reduction of arrears equivalent to 5.3 percent of GDP in 2006.
External arrears fell by a further 1 percent of GDP in 2007, while domestic arrears
declined by 0.3 percent of GDP.


                                                  6

20.        Despite posting fiscal surpluses, the fiscal position of the Government is
constrained by the need to repay large outstanding arrears, including overdue
salaries. Domestic arrears amount to an estimated 13.4 percent of GDP in 2007 and
constitute an important economic and political challenge for the Government. Largely
due to political and economic instability over 2001-2004, the CAR accumulated
payments arrears to nearly all its creditors, both external and domestic, including unpaid
salary arrears to both civilians and the military and to private suppliers. The accumulation
of domestic arrears act as an important barrier to private-sector led growth.

21.        For years the timely payment of public sector salaries has been an issue in
the CAR. Most recently, a delay in the payment of salaries in December 2007 led to
demonstrations and a public sector strike which led to a change in Government in January
2008. The payment of six months of overdue salary arrears, accumulated since the regime
change in 2003, remains an important political and social issue.4 Without additional
donor support, it is unlikely that the Government will be able to make progress on these
fronts. To date, the Government has not been in a position to repay overdue salary
arrears.

22.        Net ODA flows have fluctuated significantly in recent years, but have not
trended upwards. Total grants surged in 2006 and reached US$192.7 million due to
significant external support for arrears clearance,. In 2007 they returned to a level
estimated at US$54.5 million. As Figure 4 reveals, net ODA flows have been
significantly below total grants, reflecting significant debt obligations even after reaching
the HIPC decision point. The inability of the CAR to mobilize significant external
resources remains a cause for concern.



4 There is also pressure from public sector employees calling for a rise in salaries.

23.        The CAR reached HIPC Decision Point in September 2007, following the
completion of the Poverty Reduction Strategy and a satisfactory macroeconomic
performance under the PRGF program.5 The reduction of the CAR's NPV of debt-to-
exports ratio from 470 percent in 2006 to 150 percent would require HIPC debt relief of
US$583 million in NPV terms. This implies a common reduction factor of 68 percent.
Based on proportional burden sharing, multilateral debt relief would amount to US$365
million and bilateral and commercial debt relief to US$218 million.6 Upon reaching the
HIPC completion point, the CAR would also qualify for relief under the Multilateral Debt
Relief Initiative (MDRI), which is estimated to reduce the NPV of debt owed to IDA, the
IMF, and the African Development Bank by approximately US$110 million (in end-2006
NPV terms).



               C. MEDIUM-TERM OUTLOOK AND FINANCING REQUIREMENT

24.        Real GDP is expected to average 5 percent in the medium-term (2008-2010)
under the CAR's PRGF-supported program with the IMF (Table 1). If achieved, this
would be higher than the growth rates observed in 2006-07. This scenario presupposes
decisive domestic reforms to increase private sector investment and assumes higher
consumption due to regular payment of civil servants' wages and employment gains in
industrial and service (telecommunications) service sectors, and improvement in rural
incomes linked to intensified diamond and cotton activities. In addition, there will be


5 The CAR's public- and publicly-guaranteed external debt was estimated at US$1.1 billion in nominal
terms as of end-December 2006, equivalent to about US$ 856 million in NPV terms and 470 percent of
exports of goods and services. Multilateral debt accounted for 63 percent of the total debt, bilateral
creditors accounted for 32 percent, with the remainder of the external debt stock accounted for by
commercial creditors.
6Both figures are expressed in end-2006 NPV terms.



                                                     8

increasing external assistance to finance public investment in infrastructure, and
increasing credit to the private sector. Gross investment is projected to rise from 9.2 of
GDP in 2007 to 10.5 percent of GDP by 2010.

25.      The government's PRSP for 2008-2010 presents two medium-term growth
scenarios that depart from the latest projections under the PRGF-supported
program. Under the prudent scenario of the PRSP, real GDP growth is only 3.8 percent
in 2008, 4 percent in 2009 and 3.9 percent in 2010. This scenario assumes lower
projected growth in the food-producing sector than the latest projections under the PRGF.
It assumes that: (i) external assistance is not mobilized and spent quickly; (ii) security
problems persist; and (iii) major projects financed by private investors do not go ahead as
planned. Alternatively, in the dynamic scenario average annual GDP rises sharply as a
result of a dramatic rise in investment. Annual real GDP growth nearly doubles to 8.5
percent in 2008, accelerating to 9.7 percent in 2009 and to 11.4 percent in 2010, as
investment rises from 10 percent in 2004 to 30 percent in 2010. The assumptions of this
scenario are: (i) improved commodity prices and dollar exchange rate; (ii) consolidation
of economic stability, peace and security throughout the country; (iii) restoration of
confidence among private investors; and (iv) increased external assistance and an upturn
in external demand. Given capacity constraints, both human and institutional, it is
unlikely that investment could rise in line with the assumptions of the dynamic scenario.
The dynamic scenario also assumes external assistance of US$1.5 billion over the 2008-
2010 period, which is considerably higher than the sum pledged during the donor
roundtable held in Brussels in October 20077.

26.      Given the considerable fiscal challenges faced by the CAR, one of the
anchors of the macroeconomic program are domestic primary surplus targets. The
domestic primary balance is projected to remain positive throughout the 2008-10 period,
increasing from 0.3 percent of GDP in 2008 to 0.8 percent of GDP in 2010. Due to a
sustained increase in expenditures to support the growth and poverty reducing policy of
the Government, it will remain below the 1.1 percent of GDP attained in 2007 (Table 1).

   27.         It is projected that policy changes will raise tax revenue from 7.3 percent of
   GDP in 2007 to 7.8 percent of GDP in 2008, while the medium-term fiscal strategy
   aims to raise tax revenue to 9.9 percent of GDP in 2010 (Table 1). The government's
   strategy is to broaden the tax base, eliminate tax exemptions, improve taxation of the
   forestry sector, intensify audits of large taxpayers, improve customs revenue collection
   and rationalize taxes in the petroleum. In particular, the Government aims to: (i) update
   the tax and customs database on the basis of results of the national taxpayers survey; (ii)
   transfer customs revenue directly to accounts held in the BEAC; (iii) install a networked
   system between the tax and customs directorates and the pre-inspection company
   operating in the CAR; and (iv) redeploy Treasury agents to all line ministries generating
   revenue to ensure that such revenue is transferred to Treasury accounts. However, even
   with these efforts, tax revenue will remain very low by Sub-Saharan Africa standards and
   will act as an important constraint on the government's ability to finance public
   investment and social sector spending.



                                                   10

28.       Total expenditure is projected to rise to 15.3 percent of GDP in 2008 and to
continue to increase over the same period to reach 16.3 percent of GDP in 2010.
Domestic arrears, including salary, pensions, and supplier arrears, are expected to
continue to decline.

29.       The government's strategy also aims at a reduction of the cost of repaying
domestic debt. At present the CAR is using lines of credit and credit facilities with
commercial banks that carry high annual interest rate charges, in excess of 15 percent.
The government's debt service to commercial banks amount approximately US$10
million for 2008. Not only are interest payments high, but the government's ability to
manage liquidity is also affected negatively as commercial banks deduct due debt
payments directly from government accounts held in commercial banks.

30.       To further improve domestic debt management, the government's program
includes the option to issue regional bonds to repay domestic bank debt.8 However,
the terms and volumes the CAR may raise on regional bond markets are uncertain, would
remain subject to roll-over risk, and still imply relatively significant interest burdens
compared to concessional external financing. The Government is therefore continuing to
seek concessional external financing to help it in reducing its domestic debt, clearing
arrears, and creating needed fiscal space.

31.       In the interim, the Government has implemented several measures to
improve liquidity management. It has adopted measures to reduce the number of
government accounts by closing inactive Treasury accounts held in commercial banks. In
addition, the Government plans to review active accounts held in commercial banks, with
the aim of reducing their number and rationalizing domestic borrowing policies. In
parallel, the Government is in the process of setting rules to enhance treasury control over
government resources, especially through measures aiming to reduce automatic offsetting
mechanisms by which several institutions automatically deduct funds from government
accounts, including the pre-inspection company at the Port of Douala.




8Bond issuance will not exceed 3 percent of GDP and could reach approximately US$60 million for 2008.
A minimum of arrears clearance would be established by the Fund program in the absence of access to the
financial market.

32.        On the external front, the medium-term outlook is expected to remain
largely unchanged. The current-account deficit is expected to rise somewhat, from a
projected 4.4 percent of GDP in 2007 to 6 percent of GDP in 2010. Export growth is
projected to be fueled by developments in the timber sector, and a continued recovery of
the diamond and cotton sector. The deficit on the services account is forecast to remain



                                                         12

high as a result of import-related services and high transport costs caused by poor
infrastructure. The income account will also remain in deficit as the Government resumes
interest payments on its external debt. Despite rising surplus on the current transfers as
donors assistance resume, deficits on both these accounts would not be offset.

33.         External debt service obligations will be a significant source of outflows.
Although the CAR reached the HIPC Decision Point in September 2007, the debt service
actually paid by the country is expected to substantially increase even during the interim
period.9 This is a result of the reengagement of the CAR with the international financial
community, and also reflects a modest common reduction factor and frontloading of
interim HIPC debt relief in 2007. The CAR is expected to pay nearly US$29 million a
year in debt service during the interim period, assumed to be 2008-2009 (Table 3). In the
case of the Bank, these payments are estimated to average US$6 million for the next two
years. Debt service payments are expected to fall to approximately US$16 million after
the CAR attains HIPC Completion Point and to about US$10 million after MDRI debt
relief. This is in contrast to the situation prior to re-engagement with the donor
community, when the country made virtually no debt service payments, except to the
IMF.

34.         Significant fiscal challenges highlight the need for increased and
predictable budget support from donors. In 2007 budget support from various donors
(World Bank, EC, AfDB, France, and China) helped the Government to stay current with
salary payments and external debt payment obligations. In contrast to 2007, no budget
support was disbursed in the first quarter of 2008, and since January 2008 the
Government has been facing recurrent cash shortages and experienced difficulties to stay
current on its external debt service. Several obligations towards the Bank and the African
Development Bank (AfDB) could only be serviced with delay. Budget support, from the
AfDB, World Bank and the EC, is projected to decline in 2008, from US$45.3 million in

creditors accounted for 32 percent, with the remainder of the external debt stock accounted for by
commercial creditors. HIPC debt relief is estimated at US$538 million in end-December 2006 NPV terms.

2007 to US$26.8 million.10 The waning external support, before attaining the HIPC
completion point, forces the Government to focus on day-to-day cash management and
severely constrains the government's ability to show tangible progress from the re-
engagement with the donor community.

35.         The analysis of CAR's debt situation reinforces the need for concessional
financing and increased external financial support of the international community
along with improved economic performance. The external low-income country debt
sustainability analysis (LIC DSA) done in 2007 shows that the CAR is in debt distress
under the assumption that it reaches the floating completion point at end-2009. Key
external debt indicators in the initial years are significantly above the policy-dependent
thresholds, particularly the NPV of external debt-to-export ratio. Although these ratios
decline gradually over time under the baseline scenario of the LIC DSA, the stress tests
indicate that debt indicators are sensitive to GDP growth rates lower than assumed in the
baseline scenario and the terms of new borrowing. These vulnerabilities underscore the
importance of a stable socio-political environment and sound policies to support a
sustained improvement in economic performance. The DSA highlights the need for a
strong fiscal performance if the CAR is to meet its debt service obligations and clear
outstanding arrears.

                                             D. POVERTY OUTLOOK

36.         Household survey data, collected with the support of the UNDP, estimate
that 67.2 percent of the population lived below the poverty line in 2003.11 The

10The IMF calculated budget support for 2007 at US$27.6 million, as they exclude debt relief in the
calculation. If debt relief is included, then budget support for 2007 rises to US$45.3 million.
11 This is based on a monetary definition of poverty, where the national poverty line is equal to
CFAF156,079 (US$312) per year per adult equivalent.



                                                            14

national average hides important differences, with poverty particularly widespread in
rural areas, at 71.7 percent, which accounts for 62 percent of the population. Poverty rates
are highest in regions in which armed conflict has been most violent and lowest in the
capital, which has the best social infrastructure and highest economic activity. Since the
survey was conducted, the Government estimates that national poverty declined to 64.4
percent in 2006. According to the Poverty Participatory Analysis (2007)12, the three main
causes of poverty are (i) poor governance, with the main complaint being the abuse of
power by state officials; (ii) problems associated with insecurity or lack of peace, which
are connected to recent conflicts13, but also reflect a deterioration in economic
opportunities that have led to the proliferation of urban banditry and extortion at road
blocks, even in areas not directly affected by violent conflict; and (iii) low incomes.
These concerns are reflected in the government's PRSP.

37.       Social indicators place the CAR among the least developed countries of the
world (Table 4). The 2007/2008 UNDP Human Development Report ranks the CAR
near the bottom of its Human Development Index (171st out of 177 countries). This trend
is reflected in several health indicators: life expectancy has fallen from 44.8 years in 2000
to 43.7 years in 2005; the HIV/AIDS prevalence rate, at 6.2 percent for the 15-49 age
group in 2005, is high although considerably below the double-digit rates found in a
number of southern African countries; maternal and infant mortality rates have increased
over time.     Current policies aim to refurbish sanitation infrastructure, increase the
availability and quality of basic health care, reduce infant and maternal mortality, and
fight diseases (including malaria, tuberculosis and HIV/AIDS).                   Some encouraging
results have already been recorded. For example, the immunization program has led to a
surge in the overall national immunization rate for DPT3 to 80 percent, despite security
problems.

38.       The situation in the education sector is also bleak. Over a prolonged period,
disinvestment has taken place, resulting in the cancellation of school years, shortages in
human resources due to inadequate recruitment and salaries, a glaring lack of material
resources, and a serious deterioration in education efficiency indicators. In 2004/05, one
child out of four had never attended school, only 31 percent of children enrolled in
primary school completed primary education and repetition rate is high; only 62 percent
of those who completed primary education when they were young are literate today
(compared with 70 percent on average in other African countries). With donors'
assistance, the Government has prepared an education status report to identify constraints
for the reconstruction of the education system. It is now developing a strategy, including
quantifying and allocating the resources required, with a view to achieving the goal of
primary education for all.14

39.        Other social indicators are also very low. Only 7.6 percent of the population
uses electricity as a source of lighting. Finally, gender disparities are high, and the CAR
is ranked only 153 out of 177 countries in 2007 in terms of the gender-specific human
development index.

40.        As a result of these trends, the CAR is unlikely to achieve its MDGs by
2015. The public sector's contribution to the provision of basic social services is limited
and inequitable, which adds to the vulnerability of the poor population, while the private
sector is not equipped to fill the gaps in the provision of these basic social services.15 In
its PRSP, the Government estimated the incidence of poverty over 2006-2010 under two
scenarios. Under the prudent scenario, national poverty will decline only modestly, from
an estimated 64.4 percent in 2006 to 61.3 percent in 2010. The dynamic scenario projects
a much steeper fall in poverty, to 56.8 percent, as a result of higher economic growth and

and the Pôle de Dakar (UNESCO) elaborated an Education Country Status Report (CSR) in March 2007. A
sector-wide (including education, vocational training and literacy) financial simulation model is being
finalized for elaborating a credible scenario of long-term development of the education sector (2006-2020).

primary education; implicit subsidies for public utilities (water and electricity) are not pro-poor; in addition,
while private and/or community education provision has increased sharply in the last few years, the quality
is generally poor and more than 40 percent of teachers are community teachers, untrained and hired directly
by families.

a steep rise in public expenditure for the social sectors, infrastructure, and rural
development. However, the underlying macroeconomic assumptions of this scenario are
unlikely to be met in practice.

                    E. THE GOVERNMENT PRS AND REFORM AGENDA

41.       The Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper (PRSP) was adopted by
Government in June 2007 and presented to donors in September 2007. This first full
PRSP builds on the interim poverty reduction strategy (I-PRSP) discussed by the Boards
of the Fund and the Bank in 2001 and the interim 18-month strategy, the Economic and
Social Policy Framework (ESPF), covering 2006-2008 and adopted in November 2006.
The I-PRSP was prepared before a deep political and economic crisis confronted the
CAR in 2003. In 2005 the Government prepared an 18-month transitional strategy to lay
out its reform plans and guide its economic policy dialogue with development partners
during the critical period of re-engagement with multilateral donors.

42.       A number of specialized committees and technical groups have led the
PRSP process since its inception, and preparation for the PRSP included substantial
consultations with all stakeholders in CAR society. Over the past two and half years,
consultations have been set up centrally, regionally, and locally in seven regions, and the
participatory approach was comprehensive and integrated community preferences for
public policy interventions. The participatory approach used different methods at various
stages, such as regional workshops, quantitative and qualitative surveys of poverty
perceptions, and the use of media to reach more distant audiences to organize round
tables and gather wide-ranging opinions. In 2005 workshops took place in each of CAR's
six regions; development partners discussed drafts of the strategy and the process enabled
all stakeholders to help identify priorities and set PRSP strategic goals.

43.       The PRSP provides a detailed description of the determinants of poverty
and the profile of the poor based on the qualitative and quantitative poverty
analyses developed with the support of some key donors (World Bank and UNDP).
Although inequality is high, it is below the sub-Saharan African average. Qualitative
poverty analysis identified three priority areas for public intervention to reduce poverty:
(i) poor governance, (ii) insecurity and lack of peace, and (iii) low income and lack of
money circulating at local levels. The PRSP lays the groundwork for future diagnostic
work in these areas. Currently, a household survey is being carried out (Enquete QUIBB)
to update quantitative poverty analysis and it is expected that the Government will use the
findings of the survey to fine-tune sector-specific poverty diagnostics and policies into
sector analysis.

44.       As recognized in the PRSP, preserving macro-financial stability is crucial.
In the two macroeconomic scenarios developed in the PRSP ("prudent" and "dynamic"
scenarios), maintenance of fiscal sustainability and preserving low inflation environment
are the common objectives. The objectives of fiscal and monetary policy, embodied in
the PRGF-supported program, will support implementation of the PRSP, through
increasing domestic revenues, supporting higher spending in priority areas while keeping
inflation at its current low levels. Reducing exemptions and broadening tax base, and



                                              17

diligent implementation of modernization strategies for the internal revenue service, and
customs will be important for increasing revenue mobilization. Finally, the PRS
recognizes the potential for more revenue from natural resources (notably forestry and
mining). Full transparency in monitoring and reporting in this area--through publishing
the report of the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI) administrator in the
case of the mining sector--would contribute to realizing such a potential.

45.        The PRSP has four strategic pillars: (i) restore security, consolidate peace
and prevent conflict; (ii) promote good governance and the rule of law; (iii) rebuild
and diversify the economy; and (iv) develop human capital. After emerging from
almost a decade of political instability, armed-conflict, and poor government
effectiveness, the priority challenges are to restore peace and security, rebuild
institutions, improve social and basic infrastructure service delivery, and restore
confidence between the State and the population, these being critical pre-conditions for
growth and poverty reduction. The Government has made considerable effort to increase
spending in key sectors and the 2008 budget is better aligned with the country's
priorities. Infrastructure, defense and security, health, and education as individual item
have the highest share of the 2008 budget and increased significantly compared with the
2007 budget.16 However, room for fiscal space is small without a significant increase in
external assistance.


                    III. BANK SUPPORT TO THE GOVERNMENT'S
                                                    PROGRAM

                      A. LINK TO JOINT INTERIM STRATEGY NOTE (JISN)

46.      The Joint Interim Strategy Note (JISN), which was presented to the Board of
Executive Directors in March 2007, outlines support to the CAR planned by the
World Bank and the African Development Bank (AfDB) for 18 months (FY07-08).
The over-arching goal of the JISN is to help the CAR recover from a long period of
instability and begin laying the foundations for sustained, shared growth over the medium
term. Key features of the JISN include helping the CAR: (i) resolve its arrears to the two
institutions, and to multilateral development partners more generally, in order to restore
substantial external support to the country; (ii) begin benefiting from debt relief through
access to the HIPC and Multilateral Debt Relief (MDRI) initiatives as early as possible;
and (iii) address urgent needs on the ground, notably by rebuilding minimal effectiveness
of the Government to set and execute policy and deliver services.

47.      The JISN supports a key government objective, which is to spur economic
recovery and help strengthen public sector governance spanning public finance
management, both from the expenditure and revenue perspectives, economic governance



16As a share of the budget: Defense and security (11,58 percent); Infrastructure (12,7 percent); Education
(8,8 percent); Health (8 percent). Increase compared with 2007: Defense (59,1 percent); Equipment (28,8
percent); Health (8,6 percent); Education (4.5 percent)



                                                    18

in key sectors such as telecommunications, forestry, and mining, public administration,
and public sector governance.

48.     The JISN explicitly identifies budget support as a key aid modality, fostering
ownership, alignment with the country's development program, and domestic
accountability. Budget support for a country like the CAR is critical to ensure that the
Government has the financial maneuvering space to implementing a policy reform
package that aims to reduce fiduciary risk and enhance transparency and governance, in
order to mobilize the external donor community to step up aid commitments. It is also
critical for a country that in the past has shown difficulties in staying current on external
debt servicing--failure to pay external debt on a timely fashion can jeopardize the
reengagement process and thus lead to a suspension of donor programs, with deleterious
effects for the country's poverty and growth objectives, as set out in the PRSP. The JISN
calls for a rationalization of donor support, including a move towards co-financing or
joint operations aiming to engage the authorities at regular intervals during the budget
cycle on key development issues. In this regard, the Bank and AfDB and other donors
have increasingly endorsed government programs and strategies, using harmonized aid
modalities and relying on government processes and systems.

                         B. LINK WITH BANK GROUP OPERATIONS

49.     Reengagement and Institution-Building Support Program. The EMGRG
builds on the achievements of the Reengagement and Institution-Building Support
Program which closed on November 30, 2007. This operation set the stage for
meaningful reengagement of the donor community and assisted the CAR in its economic
and social recovery underpinned by the government's Economic and Social Policy
Framework (ESPF). It was the first IDA financing operation in the CAR since the
country went into arrears in 2001. It supported the government program focusing on: (i)
the development of key public finance to help raise domestic revenue; (ii) the
strengthening of Treasury's control over expenditures, and (iii) payroll management
system and timely payment of public wages. To increase the tax base, particular attention
was given to improving the business climate and promoting private investment in key
sectors such as mining, forestry, and telecommunications.

50.     Low-Income Countries Under Stress (LICUS) Trust Fund. Since 2004 three
projects, financed from the LICUS Trust Fund, totaling US$13.2 million, have supported
technical assistance capacity building, the PRSP process, reforms in Public Finance
Management, forestry, mining, public administration and civil service reforms, and social
service delivery. In particular, the LICUS II TF has allowed for carrying out: (i) the audit
of the Treasury, (ii) the audit of the mining sector, (iii) tax and customs administration
reforms including the audit of the fiscal system in the forestry sector, the reconciliation of
the VAT base between the BEAC and customs, and (iv) the creation of a unified payroll
management system. A recently approved LICUS project supported the implementation
of social services by protecting salary payments of civil servants in education and health
during a period of severe cash constraints in March-April 2008 until further external
resources could be mobilized. A proposed LICUS III would sustain technical assistance
to help achieve the EMGRG objectives. The LICUS III would support the



                                              19

implementation of the HIPC triggers related to the modernization of the public
administration, the implementation of the EITI, and the revision of the mining code.
Annex 6 provides details of the activities financed by LICUS Trust Funds that are
relevant to and related to this budget support operation.

51.     CEMAC Transport and Transit Facilitation project. This project aims to
secure access to landlocked countries, enhance regional integration and increase trade in
the CEMAC countries. It consists of three sub-components: (i) roads and rail investment;
(ii) investment in facilitation, inter-modal platforms and port efficiency; and (iii) support
to customs reforms and institutional support to policy improvements. CAR Component of
the project funded by IDA (US$ 24 million) mainly consists of a contribution to the
paving of the Douala-Bangui link, as well as support to road maintenance, customs
reform, and transport policy design.

52.     In addition to its direct link to the DPO I and LICUS Trust Funded
activities, the proposed Grant is integrated into the Bank's overall portfolio (Annex
5) including investment projects, and economic and sector work (ESW). IFC is involved
in activities aiming to improve the business environment, in particular (i) the preparation
of technical assistance and financing for operationalizing the one-stop shop with the
objectives of reducing the costs and procedures of opening and registering a business in
the CAR. IFC's activities are planned to start in the course of 2008 and (ii) support to
small-scale enterprises.

                      C. RELATION WITH IMF AND OTHER DONORS

53.       A limited number of key donors are active in the CAR. The EC, the IMF,
France and the UNDP are providing support in a number of areas, including public
finance management, justice sector reforms, and governance, among others.

54.       The proposed operation has been elaborated with close consultation and
coordination with the donor community active in the CAR. In particular, the AfDB
has decided to prepare its budget support operation based on the same government reform
program, the implementation of which would start with the World Bank support. The
AfDB participated in a joint-mission with the Bank in February 2008 to agree with the
Government on the same set of policy measures. The prior actions of the two-tranche
AfDB operation will be taken from the common matrix and supervision of the reform
program by both institutions will be done in a coordinated fashion. There also has been
extensive consultation with the donor community, in particular the EC, France, the IMF
and the UNDP, to ensure that there is coordination and harmonization among donor's
reform programs. The EC is providing sector and general budget support, and the general
budget support operation is currently in the design phase and alignment with the program
supported by the Bank and the AfDB is under consideration.

55.     The IMF Executive Board approved a PRGF in December 2006, supporting the
goal of economic recovery and maintaining macroeconomic stability. The core objectives
of the program are: (i) enhancing public resource mobilization and efficiency of
spending; (ii) increasing the financial sector's contribution to growth and enhancing the



                                             20

effectiveness of monetary policy; and (iii) improving the business and investment
environment. The periodic assessment of CAR's macroeconomic performance by the
Fund serves as a key input for dialogue on policies related to macroeconomic stability
and for ensuring timely payment of salaries and external debt servicing. The second
review is expected to be discussed by the IMF's Board in June 2008.

56.     The AfDB has been actively providing budget support to the Government of the
CAR to implement the country's 2007-2008 Economic Report Support Program (ERSP).
Aside from the current harmonization of support to the government program, the AfDB is
providing technical assistance in the area of debt and data management, as well as
developing capacities to design, implement, and monitor investment projects. Finally,
AfDB supports the finalizing of the procurement reforms, including the preparation of a
new Code and its operationalization.

57.       EC AREMIF (Appui a la Reforme du Ministère des Finances)project. This
project supports: (i) the upgrade of the budget and accounting nomenclatures and the
production of the new Chart of Account; (ii) the strengthening of the internal control
system (Directorate of Financial Control and the General Inspectorate of the State - IGF),
(iii) reforms in customs departments, in particular the computerization of customs
database and the strengthening of the capacity of customs agents. EC technical assistance
is also providing support to the Ministry of Finance in the design of an action plan for
customs, including the one-stop shop in Douala; and (iv) reforms in justice, in particular
the drafting of the sector strategy, the strengthening of various units and the ministry's
personnel, and the improvements of prisoners' conditions.

58.       EC Forestry Projects. The EC supports the forestry sector in CAR through
regional conservation programs. The Central Africa Forest Ecosystems (ECOFAC) which
started in the early 1990s aims at ensuring, in the long term, the preservation and
sustainable management of natural resources in the Congo Basin area. The EC also
supports a regional wildlife conservation program that focuses on endemic species such
as gorillas and elephant. The objective of the EC/WWF project, which will be effective in
April 2008, is to reduce poverty among the indigenous people living around and within
the Dzanga-Sangha protected area.

59.       UNDP. In public expenditure management, the UNDP has launched as series of
training aiming to strengthen budget preparation, especially the capacity of staff in the
Ministry of Planning and other line ministries (education, public works, health,
agriculture) to design a medium-term expenditure planning (MTEF) in line with the
PRSP objectives. In the area of tax administration, the UNDP is financing a
comprehensive tax-survey to identify potential taxpayers and reforms in public
administration and civil service. The UNDP also has active programs in the areas of
governance and justice, as well as public administration reform. In the area of
governance, the UNDP will finance technical assistance to support the Government in its
efforts to finalize an anticorruption strategy as well as for operationalizing the asset
disclosure program and planned procurement reforms.




                                             21

60.      France has a number of long-term experts working in the Ministry of Finance
(ARCAGE project) providing technical assistance to the budget and the treasury
directorate staff. In particular, France is supporting the computerization of the Directorate
of Budget and the Treasury, and the rolling out of the Integrated Financial Management
Information System (IFMIS) at the central level, which will help produce the budget
execution reports. As of December 2007, the computerization of the Treasury is
completed and that of the Directorate of the Budget is being finalized. Staffs of both
directorates are in the process of entering relevant data to produce the annual treasury
balance and budget execution reports for 2007. In forestry, the objective of the PARPAF
project is to help the forestry administration in the preparation of Forest Management
Plans for sustainable harvesting within the area allocated to logging permits. The project
whose second phase started in 2006 for a 4 year period, aims at setting the stage for
sustainable forest management in the productive forest, in a way that can perpetuate the
economic as well as the ecological functions of forests ecosystems.

61.      GTZ. The German cooperation, providing ongoing support to the forest,
focuses on the protection of biodiversity and forest ecosystems in the Dzangha ­Sangha
reserve located in the western part of the country, on the Congo Brazzaville border. It
also helps to fund a participatory forest management project and to pilot a community
development project in Lobaye in the south and Ouham in the North of the country.

                              D. ANALYTICAL UNDERPINNINGS

62.      Country Financial Accountability Assessment (CFAA) and the Public
Expenditure and Financial Accountability (PEFA). The CFAA was finalized in
October 2007. This report identified a series of deficiencies and shortcomings in the
CAR's public financial management and includes a global action plan of
recommendations on the legal and institutional framework, budget and expenditures
management, and customs and tax administration. The PEFA exercise (FY08), which is
under way, is an integrated monitoring framework that allows measurement of the
country PFM performance over time. Pinpointing strengths and weaknesses in financial
accountability arrangements in the public sector, the framework helps the Government
and donors identify priorities for reform and support both the exercise of the donors'
fiduciary responsibilities and the achievement of broader development objectives. The
exercise also facilitates harmonization of the dialogue between the Government and the
donor community around a common framework in line with the Paris Declaration, which
measures the PFM performance and contributes to reducing transaction costs for donors.
The public finance management policy areas included in the EMGRG are those identified
as critical by the CFAA and the PEFA including better control of the Treasury over
government operations and resources through, inter alia, a drastic reduction of accounts
held in commercial banks and the systematization of non-tax revenue collection at the
level of ministries; tax and customs administration efforts; effort towards comprehensive
accounting and reporting of government operations.

63.      Diagnostic Trade Integration Study (DTIS). The recently completed
Diagnostic Trade Integration Study (DTIS; FY07) report examines the constraints to
regional and international trade integration. It identifies the dire situation of the country's



                                              22

public finances as one of the significant problems that affect the country's
competitiveness through its impact on infrastructure. The continued deterioration in the
social sectors has likewise led to an erosion of the CAR's human capital, compromising
the situation for future generations. The EMGRG explicitly focuses on the need to
improve capacity of the Government to mobilize domestic revenue, through improved tax
administration. Among the findings of the report which are relevant to this operation are
those concerning the forestry sector. The DTIS recommends a thorough review of the
pricing of permits, as current pricing does not reflect regional best practice.

64.        Debt Management Performance Assessment (DEMPA). The CAR is among
the first countries selected for this debt management technical assistance. It is a technical
assistance which aims to strengthen capacity and institutions to manage government debt
in an effective and sustainable manner, by assessing performance through a
comprehensive set of performance indicators spanning the full range of government debt
management functions, highlighting strengths and weaknesses. When finished, the
DEMPA exercise, will provide a baseline of debt management performance indicators,
on which the country's future debt management performance will be assessed. It will
prove a valuable tool in assisting the Government to improve its debt management
capacity, which is particularly important in a country which has fallen into external debt
arrears.

65.        Country Procurement Issues Paper (CPIP). A CPIP was completed in April
2006, which includes an assessment of the country's public procurement system and
proposes an action plan to improve and align procurement processes with internationally-
recognized standards.17 Actions recommended in the CPIP include the adoption of a new
procurement code with regulations for standard bidding documents and guides, and the
establishment of new procurement institutions. The EMGRG would support the
government's efforts to operationalize the new procurement procedures, notably the
establishment of the Direction Générale des Marchés and the Agence de Regulation and
the decentralization of procurement processes to four key ministries, once the new
procurement code is passed by the National Assembly.

66.        Anti-corruption surveys and reports. Since 2005 the UNDP has been actively
supporting the Government of the CAR in its efforts to fight corruption. In this regard,
and in collaboration with Transparency International, it published (i) a report on the
findings of a household and company survey on the perception and causes of corruption;
and (ii) a study on corruption.18 The survey found that among private sector managers,
corruption is considered the second most pressing development priority, after security
concerns, and is a top development priority among households. The corruption study
analyzed the level of corruption, its causes and consequences, and made a series of
recommendations. Among the factors identified as contributing to the existing level of

   PNUD and Transparency International, Enquête sur la corruption auprès des ménages et des

                                                  23

corruption was the absence of a national anti-corruption strategy, as well as political and
institutional instability, generalized poverty, and a culture of tolerance vis-à-vis
corruption. Among the recommendations made by the study is the ratification of the UN
Convention against Corruption, (UNCAC), something which was done in October 2006.
The program of reforms supported by the EMGRG will support the implementation of
some of the key recommendations of the report, including the development of an
anticorruption strategy and measures aimed at enhancing transparency and accountability,
in line with the country's commitments under UNCAC.

67.     Forestry sector assessment. The Government carried out a forestry sector
assessment in 2004 to update information in the forestry sector and understand the poor
performance of the sector. This study recommended the need for ensuring that all permits
are associated with management plans, transparent allocation of permits, and the adoption
of new regulations aiming at promoting the sustainable management of productive
through the PEA which is now being incorporated in the new forestry Code. Another
study was launched in 2007 and is being finalized to assess the efficiency of the tax
collection system, compliance of private operators with the national tax regulations, the
distribution of revenues from the sector to all relevant entities including communities and
their use. The initial findings of that study suggest that there is room for improvement to
ensure transparency and competition in the system of allocation of timber harvesting
rights. Likewise, the tax collection and management systems could be improved. The
reform program supported by the EMRGR will help the Government to address issues in
tax collection in the sector.

68.     To develop analytical inputs on the environmental aspects and policy
recommendations for a potential environment and natural resource management policy
reform program, the Bank will work with the Government, development partners and
civil society organizations to prepare a Country Environmental Analysis (CEA). The
CEA will consist of three elements, focusing on (i) the costs and principle sources of
environmental degradation, (ii) institutional capacity for environmental management, and
(iii) priority sectors in which to strengthen policies, build institutions and invest for
sustainable growth. The priority sectors to be addressed in the CEA will be identified by
the Government in collaboration with development partners and civil society stakeholders
from among a variety of environmental management challenges.

                                    E. LESSONS LEARNED

69.       Reforms under the 2006 DPO helped support fiscal sustainability, in
particular due to efficient expenditure controls. Institutional and governance reforms
take time and require sustained dialogue and longer time to be implemented. Such
reforms include the revision of the regulatory framework in key sectors such as mining
and forestry as well as telecommunications. Similarly, reforms addressing the settlement
of cross-liabilities between the State and the public utility companies and limiting non-
technical losses have not resulted in substantial improvement.

70.       Lessons from the DPO I also indicate that this type of instrument is
effective in addressing a broad range of issues critical for government effectiveness,



                                              24

rebuilding institutions in a post-conflict environment, and setting the stage for
medium-term reforms. However, it also revealed that due to weak institutions, there are
practical difficulties in post-conflict countries to carry out complex reform programs.
Therefore, operations should be sharply focused and sequenced with a reasonable
milestone framework to allow for key progress. Focus should be shifted gradually from
institution- building and support to the legal and regulatory frameworks to reforms
supporting effective policy implementation. Therefore, the need for particular attention to
poverty alleviation and growth components of post-conflict programs can only be
medium-term objectives of a DPO.

71.       In the reengagement process, post-conflict countries often lack resources
due to weak revenue mobilization capacity and competing key demands which
range from security reinforcement, reconstruction program, salary payment to
social needs and debt services. Reforms need to be backed-up by pre identified sources
of financing to maximize the chance for full success. With regards the DPO I, the reasons
for the delay in implementing some of the reforms were partly the result of insufficient
financing. The same reason can also often lead to the weak effectiveness of institutions
created or strengthened under a program.


                     IV.    THE PROPOSED GRANT OPERATION

                               A. OPERATION DESCRIPTION

72.       Development objectives. The proposed EMGRG supports implementation of
the CAR's Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper in two key areas: (i) strengthening public
finance management; and (ii) improving public sector and economic governance,
understood as policies aimed at fighting corruption and enhancing transparency, as well
as reinforcing the regulatory environment in the forestry and oil. Building on the
government's achievements under RIBSUP, this new reform program will directly
support two pillars of the PRSP: (i) promoting good governance and the rule of law
(pillar 2); and (ii) rebuilding and diversifying the economy (pillar 3). The proposed
operation will support pillar 3 by strengthening the legal and regulatory framework of
two key sectors that are critical for sustaining high economic growth in the CAR: the
forestry sector, which is the second largest source of exports, and the petroleum products
sub-sector, the latter being an important input for many industries. It will also assist the
Government in working toward some of the HIPC Completion Point triggers, especially
with regards to public financial management.

73.       Benefits. This one-tranche Bank financing supports the GoCAR to implement
key policy actions in line with the PRSP objectives to improve public finances,
governance, and the regulatory framework for key sectors. Reforms supported by the
grant will thus contribute to strengthening the institutional infrastructure needed to
improve the public sector's capacity to carry out its role more effectively. In particular
the implementation of this reform program is expected to: (i) start improving the
alignment of the national budget with the PRSP objectives and establishing more
transparent and reliable fiscal reporting; (ii) improve tax revenue mobilization capacity,
reduce revenue leakages from the Treasury and enhance liquidity management; (iii)


                                             25

strengthen transparency and accountability; and (iv) establish a competitive environment
in the oil and forestry sectors. The funds provided under the EMGRG will prove critical
funds to ensure that the Government stays current on its payment obligations and to
prevent the accumulation of new salary arrears. In addition, the proposed reform program
is expected to lead to improvements in PFM and governance that should enhance the
credibility of the government's program and thus help attract more donor support, and in
particular budget support.

74.       Prior actions. The World Bank is supporting the Government in its efforts to
implement its public finance and governance reform program, following assurances that
it is committed to carry on with the implementation of these reforms. Box 1 provides a
summary of the prior actions that the Government has already undertaken to implement
the program supported by this grant operation.




                                            26

                              Box 1: Prior Actions for this Grant Operation


A. Improve the Efficiency of Public Finance Management

Prior action 1: A presidential decree has been issued to enforce new budget execution procedures, including
modalities, procedures and accountabilities for the implementation of the state budget, and nomination of
key staff in the General Directorates of Budget and Treasury.

Prior action 2: The Ministry of Finance has adopted by decision (Arrêté) a new accounting classification,
after extensive consultations with civil society and donors.

Prior action 3: The Ministry of Finance has requested by an official letter that 51 government accounts held
in commercial banks considered inactive, dormant, or settled be closed immediately and that the balance on
said accounts be transferred to a designated treasury account.

Prior action 4: The Ministry of Finance has redeployed by decision (Arrêté) 7 treasury agents to each of the
Recipient's line ministries generating revenues, including the ministries of Youth, Defense, Interior and
Public Security, Commerce, Education, Civil Service and Health, to facilitate the reporting of their
respective revenues in the Recipient's government accounts.

Prior action 5: The Ministry of Finance has adopted by decision (Arrêté), the ASYCUDA computerized
information system to produce pre clearance documents for imports entering the Recipient's territory
through the Port of Douala (Cameroon), so that it be compatible with the one used at the Recipient's central
services in Bangui.

B. Strengthening Public Sector and Economic Governance

Prior action 6: A presidential decree has been issued creating a permanent anti-corruption oversight
committee, Comité National de Lutte contre la Corruption, within the Prime Minister's office. The decree
specifies the composition of the committee and its responsibilities, including the design of an anti-
corruption strategy and oversight of the various public entities involved in the fight against corruption.

Prior action 7: The Government has strengthened fiscal compliance with national fiscal regulations in the
forestry sector and exercised of its legal remedies including: (i) cancellation of exploitation permits of two
new firms having failed to pay entry fees when due; and (ii) identifying all active forestry operators with
overdue fiscal obligations, and notifying each operator of the deadline for payment of the overdue amounts.

Prior action 8: The Ministry of Forestry has by public notice suspended the issuance of new permits, until
the CAR's forestry code has been enacted, and this has been posted on the government's website and
widely disseminated to the public.

Prior action 9: The Government has enacted a law creating the new petroleum regulatory body (Agence de
Stabilisation et de Régulation des Prix et des Produits Pétroliers), adopted its governing documents
(statuts), and nominated the General Manager, Chairman of the Board of Directors and other key staff.

Prior action 10: A contract has been signed between the petroleum regulatory agency (Agence de
Stabilisation et de Régulation des Prix et des Produits Pétrolier) and an independent pre-inspection agency
of international reputation, which will be responsible for controlling the quality of imported oil products.




                                                      27

                            Box 2. Good Practice Principles on Conditionality


Principle 1: Reinforce Ownership

·   The PRSP was approved in 2007 following extensive participation and consultations and has been
    implemented since then.
·   The country has had a positive policy reform track record.
·   The Bank has had extensive discussions with the authorities on policy options and the Government has
    designed the reforms according to its needs, notably in PFM and governance.
·   Bank involvement in the oil sector has responded to the government's demands, reflecting the need for
    advice after significant petroleum sector reforms.



Principle 2: Agree up front with the Government and other financial partners on a coordinated
accountability framework

·   The accountability framework (e.g., policy matrix) for measuring progress under the government
    program has been agreed with development partners, and is fully aligned with the AfDB.
·   The operation has been discussed with donors in the country providing budget support and the
    monitoring an evaluation system may benefit other donors aiming to participate in the medium term in
    budget support.

Principle 3: Customize the accountability framework and modalities of Bank support to country
circumstances

·   The budget support operation focuses on measures to address immediate bottlenecks in public resource
    management and governance, as part of a broader government reform strategy. They closely reflect
    urgent priorities in economic management and avoid areas of political sensitivity such as privatization.
·   The Government has expressed its policy intentions and many of the policy reforms have already been
    initiated.

Principle 4: Choose only actions critical for achieving results as conditions for disbursement

·   Prior actions and conditions focus on critical actions to assure early improvement in the management
    of public finance management and governance. All of these have already been undertaken by the
    authorities.
·   Prior actions for the forestry sector in particular represent the government's response to recent
    international concerns over transparency in the attribution of timber permits.

Principle 5: Conduct transparent progress reviews conducive to predictable and performance-based
financial support

·   The country's domestic accountability and M&E cycle is not yet established and grounded in a regular
    process.
