·   Two reviews (one formal and one informal) are planned that promote results focus taking into account
    the limited indicators available in the country and the short period available to have visible impacts (1
    year).



                                            B. POLICY AREAS

75.        Annex 2 summarizes a set of policy measures taken prior to the Board
presentation of this operation and lays out follow-on measures under the Bank-supported



                                                     28

government program. The actions are organized under two broad policy areas ­ public
finance management and public sector and economic governance.

Public Finance Management

Background and issues in public expenditure management

76.       Public expenditure management in CAR had been weak because: (i) the
annual budgeting process did not allocate sufficient resources on the basis of strategic
objectives, (ii) budget execution had been affected by several exceptional procedures and
weak internal control; (iii) no reliable accounting system had been used and several
operations had not been accounted properly; and (iv) no reliable budget reporting existed.
Both the recent CFAA and PEFA reports have highlighted continued weaknesses in
PFM, and both make recommendations which have formed the basis of the government's
own public finance reform program.19

77.       As part of the reengagement of the Bank in the CAR, the DPO I ­ the
predecessor operation - has assisted the Government in public finance management
reforms. It has been instrumental in setting the stage for a modern legal framework for
the budget, including the adoption of an organic Law and the establishment of a
consultation mechanism with line ministries and the civil society during budget
preparation. New budget classifications were also used for the 2008 budget. In addition,
under the supervision of a Treasury Committee, the number of exceptional procedures
had been reduced. Cash advances have been more closely monitored and issuance of
Treasury checks has been limited to cash-backed checks. Similarly, unforeseen
expenditures in goods and services have been controlled strictly with the creation of a
line item not exceeding 10 percent of goods and services.

78.       The predecessor operation also had as one of its objectives the settlement of
mounting arrears between public utility companies (electricity, water, and
telecommunications) and the State, and the regular payment of utility and tax bills.
The inability of the State to pay its bills is caused by insufficient budget provision for
utility consumption and has affected the financial situation of public utility companies as
well as the quality and quantity of service delivery. Small progress has been achieved
under this item: arrears to public utility companies remain high and neither the
Government nor the public utility companies had been able to pay their respective bills
on a regular basis.

79.       Several areas need continued reforms, particularly budget management
and Treasury operations, as evidenced by the first findings of the PEFA, the CFAA
and the audit of the Treasury. These inputs point to: (i) the lack of forward looking
approach of the budget and more precisely the absence of a Medium-Term Expenditure


19The draft version of the PEFA, dated January 2008, provides a comprehensive assessment of public
finance management in the CAR. It covers the: (i) credibility of the budget; (ii) transparency and
completeness of the budget; (iii) budget preparation on the basis of national policies; (iv0 the predictability
and control of budget execution; (iv) accounting and budget reporting; and (viii) surveillance and external
controls.



                                                    29

Framework, including the absence of adequate budget provisions for public utility20; (ii)
weak control of the Treasury over government resources, including revenues generated at
the level of ministries/departments and government accounts in commercial banks; and
(iii) the lack of transparent and comprehensive reporting of government operations both
at the level of the Directorate of Budget and the Treasury.

80.         The Government plans to produce timely and reliable budget reports. As a
pre condition for the production of such reports, the Government has issued a
presidential decree to enforce new budget execution procedures, including modalities,
procedures, and accountabilities for the implementation of the state budget, and
nomination of key staff in the General Directorates of the Budget and Treasury. The new
budget execution procedures draw from the CFAA and technical assistance from donors.
It aims to simplify and reduce the number of steps to be taken to process expenditures.
Among its main features are the autonomy and the reduction of the number of
interventions of the Financial Commitment Control. It also improves the legal framework
governing the role of the officials to authorize payments. In addition, staff nomination of
key at the level of the Directorate of budget and the Treasury will ensure proper
functioning of the new dispositions and celerity in budget processing.

81.         The Government plans to include budget provisions for arrears to public
utilities. Given the importance of the electricity, water, and telecommunications sector
for the private sector and the population, there is a need to address the stock of arrears
and government utility bill payment which are critical for improving the financial
performance and service delivery of the companies concerned. The reduction of arrears
will be informed by the audit of domestic arrears for 2005-07.

82.         Key next steps include:

     ·      Production of timely quarterly budget execution reports from commitment to
     authorization for health, education, equipment/infrastructure, and agriculture
     ministries. As of February 2007, the computerization of the Directorate of Budget is
     being completed and staffs are finalizing the upload of the 2007-data in the system to
     produce the 2007-administrative accounts while starting to input data for 2008. The
     Government is expected to produce quarterly budget execution reports for key
     ministries from March 2008 onwards.

     ·      Submission of the 2008 Execution Law to the Parliament. The above step will
     lead to the production of the 2008 annual budget execution report and the submission
     of the 2008 Execution Law to the National Assembly for the first time in CAR.

     ·      Inclusion of a budget line in the 2009 budget for payment of government arrears
     to ENERCA, SODECA, SOCATEL. In addition, an action plan addressing chronic
     government arrears and ensuring utility bill payment with measures to be
     implemented during the course of 2008 will be produced by a Committee under the


20This operation will not address budget preparation. The UNDP is already supporting Government in its
effort to establish a MTEF and its operationalization in the 2009 budget.



                                                     30

    lead of the Minister of Finance with representatives from public utility companies and
    line ministries involved. The target is to reduce by 10 percent the overall outstanding
    stock of arrears, compared to the level at end-2007. The Fund program will support a
    timetable to repay the arrears over 10 years.

83.       The Government has also adopted several measures to improve the
efficiency and transparency of the accounting system. These reforms strengthen the
accounting system, and improve the treasury's control over government's operations and
its reporting capacity. Immediate actions under this operation include: (i) the adoption of
a new accounting classification; and (ii) the closure of inactive accounts in BEAC and
commercial banks.

84.       The Minister of Finance has adopted by decision (Arrete) a new accounting
classification, finalized after extensive consultations with civil society and donors. The
new accounting nomenclature, which will ensure comprehensive accounting of
government operations, has been finalized and validated by the authorities after extensive
consultations with civil society and donors. A first draft had been produced and presented
to a broader audience (civil society, donors) in the third week of February. The new
accounting nomenclature will allow for adjustments to the new budget classification if
necessary to account for all government operations.

85.     The Minister of Finance has requested by an official letter that 51 government
accounts held in commercial banks considered inactive, dormant, or settled be closed
immediately and that the balance on said accounts be transferred to a designated
treasury account. This operation supports the government's initiative to reduce the
number of government accounts in commercial banks. The control by the Treasury of
these accounts is often poor, thereby undermining liquidity management and the
comprehensiveness of the accounting of government operations and reporting. A number
of accounts had been identified by the technical assistance of the Fund and the audit of
the Treasury financed by a LICUS TF to determine the final number of accounts, their
nature and dates of closure. As of end March 2008, 51 accounts in commercial banks
have been closed, and the balances transferred to a treasury account.

86.        Key next steps include:

    ·     Propose a list of accounts to be closed and transfer of their respective balance
    to a Treasury account under the control of the Directorate of the Treasury within a
    defined time line based on an audit by IGF of existing government bank accounts held
    in commercial banks followed by an independent review/audit of accounts with
    negative balance. Closing government accounts held in commercial banks, in
    addition to the 51 already closed, will require an audit and a processing schedule
    which will vary according to the nature of the accounts. Future measures are: (i) the
    audit of accounts in commercial banks, the results of which are to be reviewed by an
    independent auditor for accounts with negative balance; (ii) the production of list of
    accounts to be transferred to a Treasury account; and (iii) the production of a list of
    accounts to be closed within a defined period. Such actions would contribute to the




                                             31

    comprehensiveness of the accounting system and ensure transparency of government
    operations reporting.

    ·     Audit of the 2005-07 domestic arrears vetted by the authorities. The
    Government validated recently an audit of the 1998-2004 arrears and a corresponding
    settlement plan. New debt and arrears have been accumulated between 2004 and 2007
    including 6-month salary arrears. In order to account for the operations between 2004
    and 2007 in government operations and start implementing a settlement plan, the
    authorities need to validate the 2005-07 period arrears. The Government will conduct
    an audit of the 2005-07 arrears by the IGF to be vetted by the authorities.

    ·     Production of the 2008 government accounts. With the computerization of the
    Treasury and Budget operations and the new accounting classifications, the
    Government plans to produce the 2008 government accounts for the first time. While
    the data for 2008 will be uploaded on a regular basis, a unit will be created within the
    Treasury to consolidate and input the relevant data for the 2007 operations.

Background and issues in domestic revenue mobilization

87.       Averaging 7 percent of GDP over the last decade, CAR's domestic revenue is
among the lowest in the world due to small tax base, and weak revenue mobilization
capacity, including lack of adequate equipment. In particular, customs administration was
affected by corruption and resources and revenues collected by line ministries have not
been fully controlled by the Treasury. In an attempt to revamp the customs system, the
authorities abolished the customs office in the fall of 2006 and created a new one which
was approved by the IMF later in the same year and the Government has contracted a
private operator to run a pre clearance office. Under an EC technical assistance, the
Government also completed the networking of the customs offices between CAR
customs in Douala and Bangui with ASYCUDA, the automated system for customs data.

88.       Under the predecessor operation, the Government (i) completed an audit of the
performance of the pre-clearance system in Douala to assess its performance. The main
recommendation of the audit pointed to the need to establish final clearance of imports in
Douala or in Bangui, and to secure the transit system from Douala to Bangui; and (ii)
launched a comprehensive national survey to identify potential taxpayers and to increase
the tax base. The Government also made progress in capturing revenue generated and
declared by line ministries which increased from CFAF4 billion to CFAF13-14 billion
between 2005 and 2007. Finally, the Auditor General (Inspection Générale de l'Etat)
and the General Inspectorate of the State (Inspection Générale des Finances) conducted
audits (i) to identify additional sources of revenues at the level of these entities and (ii) to
define the share of revenues collected by these ministries that should be retained at their
level to finance specific activities.

89.       Key institutional distortions negatively affect the CAR's ability to mobilize
domestic revenue: (i) the existing pre clearance office, run by a private operator, uses a
different database system to issue the required pre clearance documents. Such a
duplication increases the risk of corruption as the database system in Bangui is not linked



                                              32

to the system in Douala, thereby reducing the authorities' ability to trace and value goods
adequately; (ii) customs receipts are transferred to commercial banks rather than central
bank government accounts, thereby adversely affecting the cash management of the
Treasury, as commercial banks automatically offset domestic debt services directly with
government resources at their disposal; and (iii) submissions of revenue generated at the
level of line ministries are made without proper accounting procedures and direct control
of treasury agents.

90.       This reform program supports government actions to improve domestic
revenue mobilization capacity. Immediate measures supported under the grant include
(i) the redeployment of treasury agents to all line ministries generating revenue, and (ii)
the use of ASYCUDA for all customs transactions. This measure complements recent
initiatives to increase tax revenues, namely capacity building for customs agents and the
computerization of the customs database by the European Commission and the start of a
initiative jointly funded by the EC and IDA at a regional level to secure a more cost
effective transit regime on the corridor between Douala and Bangui.

91.       The Minister of Finance has redeployed by decision (Arrete) 7 treasury agents
to each of the Recipient's line ministries generating revenues, including the ministries of
Youth, Defense, Interior and Public Security, Commerce, Education, Civil Service and
Health, to facilitate the reporting of their respective revenues in the Recipient's
government accounts. In December 2007 the Government had already started the process
of redeployment of Treasury agents to the ministries of Finance, Planning, Public Works,
Mining and Energy, Justice, and Communications. To systematize capturing of non-tax
revenues at the level of line ministries, the Minister of Finance has redeployed seven
treasury agents to additional seven line ministries. The redeployment of Treasury agents
in 2008 means that all line ministries generating revenues are now covered. These
reforms will also help use adequate accounting system to incorporate the global amount
of these revenues in the government accounts.

92.       The Minister of Finance has adopted by decision (Arrete), the ASYCUDA
computerized information system to produce pre clearance documents for imports
entering the Recipient's territory through the Port of Douala (Cameroon), so that it be
compatible with the one used at the Recipient's central services in Bangui. The
recommendations of the recently completed audit of the pre clearance office in Douala
point to the need to revise the process, especially to use a single system linking the
offices in Douala and Bangui to improve the traceability of imported goods as well as
that of the value declared by importers. Data submitted through ASYCUDA in Douala
has now been locked in a networked system between Douala and Bangui, which will
reduce the risk of corruption, thereby strenghtening the control of the customs office in
Bangui.

93.       Key next steps include:

    ·     Transfer of customs revenue to account held in BEAC. Customs receipts both
    from the pre clearance system and the final declaration in Bangui are deposited at
    commercial banks. The Government will replace this system with a direct transfer of



                                            33

    customs receipts to the Central Bank in Douala and Bangui. Such a measure will
    provide the Treasury with full control on government resources and improve cash
    management. Treasury agents will be posted in Douala and will be in charge of
    depositing at the BEAC customs receipts from the pre clearance system.

    ·    Install networked systems between the tax and customs directorates and the pre
    inspection company. The connection of ASYCUDA between the customs offices in
    Douala and Bangui has been completed recently and offers opportunity to better track
    movements of imported goods. In order to further improve data management and the
    tracking and predictability of import and export tax receipts, the program proposes
    the connection of the pre inspection company BIVAC with the customs offices to
    complete the networking of all entities involved in trading across borders.

    ·    Update the tax and customs database based on the results of the 2007 national
    surveys. The Government would use the results of the survey to identify potential
    taxpayers to update the taxpayer database under SYSTEMIF (tax administration) and
    ASYCUDA (customs), with the aim of increasing the tax base.


Public Sector and Economic Governance

Background and issues for anti-corruption

94.      CAR ranks well below the average of Sub-Saharan Africa in all of the World
Bank Institute's governance indicators, particularly those measuring government
effectiveness and rule of law, where the CAR ranks in the bottom 10 percent worldwide.
As a signatory to the UN Convention against Corruption (UNCAC), the Government has
committed to implement a wide-range of reforms aimed at strengthening transparency
and accountability, and it is expected that these will eventually translate into
improvements in the CAR's governance indicators, which the Government is monitoring
closely.

95.      Under the predecessor operation, the Government was successful in
revamping a set of institutions including: (i) an operational branch of the judiciary, the
"Tribunal de Grande Instance" to better monitor the processing of filed cases, (ii) the
Pôle Financier du Tribunal de Grande Instance de Bangui (it is a special section of the
tribunal created in July 2005, with a mandate to investigate fiscal, financial, and customs
fraud, as well as trafficking of influence), (iii) the Agence Nationale d'Investigation
Financière (ANIF), created in September 2007 to investigate money laundering and
terrorism. These measures have led to a significant increase in the number of cases of
suspected corruption under investigation, over 287 individuals since 2006, and in the
number of penalties imposed. It has also allowed the strengthening of the accountability
of the Executive through asset disclosure of the Prime Minister and cabinet members at
entry and exit.

96.      The effectiveness of some of these anti-corruption entities has been
hampered by a number of factors. In particular, the absence of a well identified anti-
corruption interlocutor and coordinator or reform champion within the Government,


                                             34

helps explain in part the delays in producing an anti-corruption strategy and in
operationalizing new agencies aimed at fighting corruption. In this regard, a temporary
committee, the Comité de Réflexion sur la Corruption (CRC) was established in 2005,
with the aim of devising an anticorruption strategy until a permanent anti-corruption
institution was created. This committee, which is no longer operational, suffered from a
number of shortcomings which made its functioning ineffective. Among these
shortcomings was the decision to exclude the Ministry of Justice, civil society and key
private sector representatives as committee members, as well as the decision to have the
CRC chaired by a line ministry. Given the sensitivity of anti-corruption reforms, there
was unwillingness among line ministries to assume responsibility for championing
reforms. Experience from other countries suggests that anti-corruption efforts work best
when championed and sanctioned by the President or Prime Minister.

97.       The Government is strengthening the formulation, coordination and
monitoring of anti-corruption policies. The Recipient has established by a presidential
decree a permanent anti-corruption oversight committee, Comité National de Lutte
contre la Corruption, within the Prime Minister's office.          The decree specifies the
composition of the committee and its responsibilities, including the design of an anti-
corruption strategy and oversight of the various public entities involved in the fight
against corruption. The committee has a broad mandate to formulate, coordinate and
monitor anti-corruption efforts, which will provide the CAR with an improved
framework and oversight mechanism to strengthen governance and to increase the
visibility of these efforts. The new committee is responsible for implementing,
monitoring and overseeing the other anti-corruption measures envisaged by the
Government.

98.       Key next steps include:

    ·     Production and dissemination of an anti-corruption strategy.            Combating
    corruption requires an approach that addresses the many causes, facets and structural
    issues that give rise to corruption. It also requires courage, leadership, and a long-
    term commitment by a variety of anticorruption actors. Political leaders, champions
    amongst public servants, civil society, media, academics, the private sector and
    international organizations all play important roles in addressing corruption. The
    newly created committee, which also has representatives from business groups and
    civil society, would be responsible for elaborating and disseminating a national
    strategy to fight corruption. In this regard, the UNDP, together with Transparency
    International, have already carried out household and firm corruption perception
    surveys.

    ·     Production and dissemination of an annual program of activities of the
    Committee and the production of an annual report summarizing the efforts of the
    Government to be presented to the National Assembly. This measure aims to
    strengthen the government's medium-term strategy and ensure that it focuses on
    concrete, actionable activities. It also aims to ensure that the committee is accountable
    to both the Government and National Assembly, and that its efforts are summarized
    in a widely disseminated report that is publicly available. This will allow feedback



                                               35

   from the general public, civil society, and the donor community, for moving the
   reform agenda forward. In addition, it will give a higher level of visibility to the
   government's concerted anti-corruption efforts, which engage a wide number of
   agencies and institutions.

   ·     Issue a decree concerning asset disclosure by government members, including
   sanctions and verification mechanism; specify a standard format and guidelines for
   submission. The Government took an important step in 2007, when it enforced the
   provisions of the Constitution, particularly Article 44 with regard to the declaration of
   assets by the Prime Minister and other cabinet members. However, no law or decree
   stipulates the form in which the declaration must be made. In practice, this has
   translated into a great deal of variability in terms of what assets were included in the
   declarations and the level of details provided. In addition, although the Constitution
   specifies that the declaration must be presented to the Constitutional Court within 60
   days of assuming power, in practice there are no sanctions for not meeting this
   deadline or for not submitting a declaration. In order to strengthen these lacunae in
   the existing framework it is critical to ensure that the declaration of assets helps to
   improve the accountability of high level government officials by issuing a decree
   governing asset disclosure, specifying who must declare assets, the form and content
   of the disclosure, the sanctions for not abiding by the deadline or for failing to submit,
   and ensuring that the declarations are open to scrutiny by making them publicly
   available, as per Article 44      of the Constitution. A standard format for asset
   disclosure, as outlined in the decree, will need to be used when submitting the
   declarations. To ensure success, it is contemplated that a workshop will be held to
   explain the new dispositions and ensure correct filling of the asset disclosure form.

   ·     Increase transparency in the area of publicly available information. One of the
   prior actions of the RIBSUP operation was the publication in the government's
   website of a (i) summary of all mining agreements containing the key clauses
   (including financial and tax related terms and conditions, duration and amounts
   received as signature bonuses and equity shares; and (ii) documents evidencing the
   transfer of the amounts received (as bonuses or equity shares) in the public accounts,
   as well as an indication of how the funds were used. Over the next year, the
   Government intends to extend the information included in its website to include: (i)
   mining and forestry concessions; (ii) Treasury reports; (iii) annual and quarterly
   budget reports; (iv) budget laws; (v) annual reports of the anticorruption committee;
   (vi) new mining, forestry and procurement codes, and (vii) customs revenue
   collection on a quarterly basis and disclosure of customs performance indicators,
   which is spelled out in the covenant of the CEMAC TTF project.

Background and issues in procurement

99.      A thorough review of the procurement process, including the legal and
regulatory aspects, was finalized by the Government in 2006 and a final study was
produced, the Country Procurement Issues Paper (CPIP). Based on the conclusions of this
study, the Government is in the process of implementing an action plan to strengthen the
legal and regulatory framework to operationalize the main recommendations of the



                                             36

procurement strategy in CAR. The World Bank and AfDB have started financing experts
who have as their mission: (i) to provide technical assistance to the CAR's working group
reviewing national procurement practice and its legal and regulatory framework. The
objective of this review is to identify the weaknesses and strengths of procurement and
establish an action plan of reform priorities; (ii) finalize a new procurement Code; and
(iii) start its implementation. Satisfactory implementation of the new Code is one of the
sub-components of the public finance management HIPC Completion Point trigger.

100.       The Government plans to improve the clarity and efficiency of public
procurement processes. During the course of 2008, the Government plans to take
measures aimed at operationalizing the new institutions created by the procurement code,
once it is adopted by the National Assembly. These include: (i) nomination of members
of the new Direction Générale des Marchés (the General Directorate of Procurement)
and the Agence de Régulation de Passation des Marchés (the Regulatory Agency of
Procurement); (ii) production of manuals of procedure and standard bidding documents;
(iii) operationalization the procurement departments within four key ministries
(education, health, agriculture and infrastructure); and (iv) compliance review with new
procurement procedures via a post-procurement review (PPR).

101.       Key next steps include:

     ·     Nomination of members of the new Direction Générale des Marchés (DGM)
     and the Agence de Régulation de Passation des Marchés (ADM). A fundamental
     aspect of the new procurement code is the creation of the DGM and the ADM. The
     DGM will be a separate direction within the Ministry of Finance, involved with
     overall oversight of the procurement process. The ADM will be responsible for
     regulating the procurement process, as well as the entity which will deal with disputes
     and complaints regarding the bidding process. It will be responsible for modifications
     and amendments to procurement rules and regulations, and will produce annual audit
     reports on new tenders.

     ·     Production of manuals of procedures and standard bidding documents. The
     purpose of the manual is to familiarize employees in the DGM and the ADM with the
     new purchasing practices with regard to the goals, benefits and policies as well as
     what the department expects with regard to performance and conduct. It will provide
     an overall description of the department's purchasing program, which represents the
     minimum requirements for departments to obtain and maintain any type of
     purchasing authority. It addresses the statutes, regulations, policies, procedures and
     best practices applicable to all facets of statewide purchasing authority. Likewise, the
     preparation of standard bidding documents aims to ensure that new bids are submitted
     as per the requirements of the new procurement code. Both aspects are part of the
     process of implementing the new procurement rules and regulations.

     ·     Operationalize the procurement departments within four key ministries
     (education, health, agriculture, and public works). The new procurement code calls
     for the decentralization of procurement, including the invitation to tender function
     and the controls over the bidding process, to be carried out by line ministries. This



                                               37

    measure aims to start the operationalization of this policy in four key ministries which
    have the largest number of tenders.

    ·     Review compliance with new procurement procedures via a post-procurement
    review (PPR). This review aims to ensure that the new institutions that have been put
    in place are staffed and functioning adequately in line with the new procurement
    code.

Background and issues for the forestry sector

102.      Improving transparency in the management of natural resources has been an
important government priority, both in mining and forestry. Significant progress has been
made by CAR in mining under the predecessor operation with the start of the
implementation of steps leading to the EITI, the revision of the mining Code, and the
completion of the audits of signatures bonuses, equity and their use since 2004. Mining
will not be addressed under this one-year operation as most of these activities are already
HIPC triggers, and if completed within one year would be a significant achievement.

103.      Governance effort has also been reflected in work started under the predecessor
operation to revise a new forestry code that ensures that timber harvesting rights are
allocated on the basis of market mechanisms and that forestry taxes are collected as per
rules and regulations. The new Code, which is being finalized and is expected to be
passed by the National Assembly later this year during the April-June 2008 session, has
been revised in order to: (i) modernize and strengthen the dispositions pertaining to the
preparation and implementation of forestry management plans; (ii) revise criteria for
attribution of harvesting permits; (iii) tighten tax reporting and collection arrangements;
(iv) improve arrangements for sharing forestry revenue with forestry communities; and
(v) enhance the feasibility of small-scale forestry and community access to forest
markets, thereby ensuring sustainable resource use.

104.      A government review of the fiscal obligations of firms operating in the sector
highlighted two issues: (i) two new firms in the sector that were awarded permits in
December 2007 did not comply with the national regulations and law which obligate new
firms to pay the equivalent of 3 years of annual flat fees within 14 days following the
notification of awarding of contract. Penalty as spelled out in the official texts is the
immediate withdrawal of the permits of any defaulting firms, and (ii) some already active
firms were not current on tax payment (VAT) and other fiscal obligations. For active
firms failing to pay taxes, there is a moratorium of three months granted by the
Government, beyond which penalty should be enforced.

105.      The Government is committed to improving compliance with forestry laws
and regulations. Prior actions completed under this operation include: (i) actions to
initiate due process for firms not complying with national fiscal regulations; and (ii) and
the suspension of issuance of new permits before the draft forestry code is enacted.

106.      The Recipient has strengthened fiscal compliance with national fiscal
regulations in the forestry sector and exercised of its legal remedies including: (i)



                                              38

cancellation of exploitation permits of two new firms having failed to pay entry fees when
due; and (ii) identifying all active forestry operators with overdue fiscal obligations, and
notifying each operator of the deadline for payment of the overdue amounts. In February
2008 the Government cancelled the two permits awarded in December 2007, in strict
compliance with national regulations which have provisions for not complying with fiscal
obligations. In addition, the Ministry of Forestry has also sent a letter to each active firm
with taxes and fees payment overdue, notifying the operator of the deadline for payment
of the overdue amounts. As of March 25, 2008, all overdue VAT payments have been
made and commitment has been obtained from private operators for other tax and fee
payments to settling all tax obligations.

107.      The Minister of Forestry has suspended the issuance of new permits, until the
CAR's forestry code has been enacted, by public notice, posted on the government's
website and widely disseminated to the public. Through a public notice the Government
has suspended the issuance of new forestry permits until the adoption of the new forestry
code, which has been posted on the government's website and been widely disseminated
to the public. This measure will ensure that new permits will be granted according to
international practice including sustainable and community-based forestry management.

108.      Key next steps include:

    ·       Address VAT cross-liabilities between the State and operators and re-
    establish regular payment of all fiscal obligations to be paid by operators. As a result
    of overdue value-added tax (VAT) refunds, it is at present difficult to establish
    whether forestry operators are paying taxes due to the State, as they are in effect only
    paying the net value, subtracting tax refunds owed by the State. A first step to solve
    this situation is to determine the cross-liabilities between the State and operators in
    the forestry sector through an audit of the IGF. Once the level of cross-liabilities is
    known, it is important to re-establish a regular payment of VAT refunds on the part of
    the State, in compliance with existing laws and regulations, and to ensure that forestry
    operators pay due taxes. Another measure regarding the current fiscal dispositions
    concerns the redress of tax payments due to Communes by private operators with a
    gap of approximately CFAF 138 million. The Government will follow up in a
    subsequent phase and remedies will be exercised to re establish regular and full
    payment of all fiscal obligations due by private operators. As of the second week of
    March 2008, the Government already obtained commitment from active operating
    firms to settle all pending fiscal obligations, demonstrating its capacity to maintain
    dialogue with the private sector. This measure complements the HIPC trigger, which
    requires making publicly available the amount of government proceeds from the
    sector, their use, including the revenue sharing between the central Government, the
    communes, and communities.

Background and issues for the oil sector

109.      The proposed EMGRG aims to address governance issues in the oil sector,
a sector not covered in the earlier budget support operation. The Government has
started reforms in the oil sector with the enactment of a new Law in the first half of 2007,



                                              39

which touches upon several domains, including imports, storage, distribution, and pricing
of petroleum products, with an emphasis on opening the market to competition (see Box
3). With the liberalization of the downstream petroleum sector, a new firm in charge of
the storage of oil products ­ SOCASP - was officially created.21 In addition, a new
regulatory body has been created, the Agence de Stabilisation et de Régulation des Prix
des Produits Pétroliers, whose role is to ensure that existing as well as new actors
entering the market meet the standards required to operate in this trade, to ensure full
compliance with the national regulation and ensure adequate control quality of oil
products. A financing mechanism has already been identified, embedded within the
pricing formula of oil products, to make sure that the regulatory agency is self-financing.

110.        The operation proposes supporting government measures aimed at
strengthening the regulatory framework in the oil sector through (i) the
strengthening of the newly created regulatory agency; and (ii) ensuring the quality of
imported petroleum products throughout the value chain.

111.        The Recipient has enacted a law creating the new petroleum regulatory body
(Agence de Stabilisation et de Régulation des Prix et des Produits Pétroliers) and
adopted its governing documents (statuts) by decree, nominating the General Manager,
Chairman of the Board of Directors and other key staff. Until such time as market forces
will freely set prices on an import parity basis, the market will need to be monitored and
regulated at first, to secure operators and consumers alike, from any form of abuse or
collusion. Adequate staffing and capacity building of the staff at the regulatory agency
will (i) make it fully operational; (ii) ensure that new firms entering the market meet all
required criteria to operate in CAR as per the new Law and sector regulations, (iii) enable
it to ensure adequate market monitoring, proper regulation and enforcement of pertinent
rules regarding petroleum products specifications, safe transport and handling; and (iv)
secure much needed tax revenue flows.




21The State has a 51 percent stake, TOTAL of France 25 percent, TRADEX of Cameroun 15 percent, and
the local private sector a 9 percent stake.



                                                 40

                                      Box 3: Oil Sector Restructuring

An institutional crisis erupted between the Government and the then sole petroleum importer and main
supplier (TOTAL Centrafrique) in the spring of 2007. The crisis was triggered by several endogenous and
exogenous factors, including the sudden increase in petroleum prices worldwide and the related increase in
transport and financial services costs. A new Law was adopted by the Parliament to restructure the
downstream petroleum sector and the company in charge of oil imports, storage and distribution, SOGAL.
The new Law includes dispositions to grant the majority of the shares to the State while providing room for
new entrants in the sector. The creation of a Regulatory Agency is included in the new Law to supervise the
sector and ensure that it becomes open, fair, transparent, and eventually competitive. Finally, it also
provides an opportunity to reach an understanding on pricing issues and implement reforms to generate a
more sustained and predictable stream of fiscal revenues to the Treasury. The expected fiscal revenue
would be derived from improved operational efficiency and enhanced competition, cost-cutting as well as
an improved tax base. The parties involved requested the Bank's assistance to help mitigate the crisis. The
Bank responded with a fact-finding mission in July-August 2007 which was complemented by another
review mission in December 2007.

Several issues have been raised by both government representatives and importers regarding tax and duty
arrears and the structure of the pricing formula (the rationale for CIF cargoes from loading ports in North
West Europe instead of closer references in the Mediterranean, the oversize ships used leading to costly
freight and insurance, demurrages costs built in the pricing formula, whereas they should be the exception
and not the rule, and finally open access to the documents pertaining to the transactions executed in 2006
and 2007 - Bills of lading - to use them as a learning tool for improving a new pricing structure). The Bank
played a facilitating role during the negotiations scheduled in two stages: (i) first, the settlement of terms
according to the new institutional and legal framework created by the April-2007 Law and its
implementation through well designed and drafted legislation, adapted to present market conditions; (ii) the
determination of the pricing formula through an interim approach and leading to the preparation of a more
permanent pricing structure. The performance of the new pricing structure is to be re-examined on a yearly
basis, three month before the end of the "River season" to allow for any corrective action to take place the
following year. The Committee reached a number of agreements on several items including switching to
the FOB-Mediterranean reference point instead of the CIF-North West Europe reference point.

As of February 2008, several transport and transit issues are still pending, until pertinent documentation is
provided by importers such as bills of lading for 2006-2007, justification of higher transit and other charges
in DRC, and the settlement of all taxes and duties cross-liabilities during the first half of 2008. Meanwhile
an agreement has been reached between the State and current operators regarding the stakeholders'
participation in the new oil company, SOCASP: the State now holds 51 percent share, TOTAL
Centrafrique opted for 25 percent and the position of Deputy Directorship on the Board of SOCASP, with
responsibilities that include broad technical assistance and the import and monitoring of all aviation fuels
(Jet A1 and Avgas for smaller planes) for which it is internationally qualified and insured; another private
operator (Tradex of Cameroun) has a 10 percent stake and three other private entities have 3 percent each.
Finally, both parties agreed officially through an official note to withdraw any legal disputes in the hands of
the Court following the constitution of SOCASP and the compensation of SOGAL's shareholders and
assets, which amount to $US2.5 million.



112.       A contract has been signed between the petroleum regulatory agency (Agence
de Stabilisation et de Régulation des Prix et des Produits Pétrolier) and an independent
pre-inspection agency of international reputation, which will be responsible for
controlling the quality of imported oil products. This measure aims to ensure high quality
petroleum product imports, by establishing a contractual relationship with an inspection
company that is properly staffed and equipped to test the quality of all petroleum
products imported into the CAR.




                                                      41

113.      Key next steps are to establish new downstream petroleum sector
legislation in conformity with international best practice. This measure aims to ensure
that existing national legislation is brought into conformity with international best
practice to protect the interest of both the Government and the private sector, including
consumers. In this regard, the World Bank will provide technical assistance, through the
LICUS III Trust Fund, to ensure that this objective is met.


                        V. OPERATION IMPLEMENTATION

                             A. POVERTY AND SOCIAL IMPACT

114.      The actions supported by the grant are expected to have significant positive
poverty and social impacts. Joint World Bank and IMF staff assessments of the CAR's
PRSP have emphasized the need for the poverty strategy to be more explicit on key
priorities and budgetary allocations. They also recommended a strengthening of its
monitoring and evaluation system. To achieve faster poverty reduction and progress
towards the MDGs, this development policy operation focuses on public expenditure
management that will better link the PRSP to the budget and enhance public expenditure
efficiency. Improved fiscal reporting should make it easier to scrutinize the extent to
which voted budget allocations and actual public expenditures are in line with the PRSP
objectives. In this sense, the public finance measures included in the EMGRG will make
it easier to track public expenditures in order to ensure that there is increasing actual
expenditures in key priority sectors, including health and education, in line with the
PRSP.

115.      As spelled out in the PRSP, corruption and poor governance are perceived
to be the top causes of poverty. The EMGRG proposes measures aimed at supporting
the government's efforts to fight corruption, improve procurement processes, and
enhance transparency and accountability. It will help ensure that domestic and external
resources are used effectively, minimizing fungibility, and state capture. In addition, the
oil and forestry reforms are expected to ensure regular flows of tax revenues to the
Government and reduce capture by vested interests. Finally, customs reforms are
expected to increase not only resource availability, but also the amount of tax revenues
paid without increasing the burden on the poor. Taken together, these measures should
improve the distributional properties of state activity, benefiting the poor segments of
society through better services without raising tax burdens.

                               B. ENVIRONMENTAL ASPECTS

116.      The proposed grant focuses primarily on institutional reforms, with limited
environmental implications. Oil sector reforms are expected to lead to strengthened
enforcement of legislation in the petroleum sector, and to stricter compliance with quality
and operational standards, with no expected negative consequences for the environment.
Further, the Bank will support the strengthening of the Regulatory Agency through an
upcoming LICUS grant to address a range of issues, including environmental
management in the petroleum sector.



                                             42

117.      Reforms in the forestry sector are expected to have positive environmental
consequences.      These reforms aim to strengthen the government's oversight of the
forestry permit processes. The moratorium on issuing new licenses will ensure that
future permits will fall under an improved new Forest Code reflecting international best
practice, including the use of international observers and inclusive forestry management.
It will also balance community access and commercial use of forest resources for revenue
generation, in line with PRSP objectives. The Government is finalizing the new Forest
Code with assistance from donors, including the Bank, and it is expected to pass the
National Assembly during the April-June 2008 session. The impact on revenue and
illegal logging of the short delay in attributing remaining permits is not expected to be
significant.

118.      The forest sector reforms build on good information on forest management
issues in the CAR, and draw on the long-term engagement of development partners,
including significant support for institutional strengthening. Since 2005, timber
exports have been monitored on behalf of the Government by an independent body with
the mandate to ensure compliance with operational requirements from logging sites to
export points, and to fight against illegal logging. Specific activities include inspection of
waybills for transportation of timber products, mill entry and exit books, and the cross-
checking of species and volumes of timber exported with the collection of equivalent
export taxes. The independent monitoring contract also has a capacity building
component for both the forestry and customs administrations that promotes knowledge
transfer to local staff.

119.       Building on the results of the forest sector assistance provided by AFD through
the PARPAF project, which helped establish a forest Geographic Information System
(GIS), forest administration capacity has also been strengthened through an agreement
signed in 2007 between the Government and the World Resources Institute (WRI),
funded by USAID through the Central Africa Regional Environmental Program
(CARPE). Under this contract, WRI is helping the forest administration in mapping
logging areas, protected areas, as well as hunting and safari zones, with field inspections
being conducted in logging areas by a special unit of the forest administration. Specific
attention is being paid to the monitoring of logging activities and the enforcement of
forest management plans. The system allows the forest administration to compare timber
harvests with the results of forests inventories, monitor skid trails and logging roads, and
check compliance with other management requirements in order to ensure sustainable
management of forest.

120.      Under current regulations, local populations are consulted prior to the award of
timber harvesting rights to a private operator. The company selected is required to
organize a consultative meeting with neighboring communities so that local people can
express their concerns about traditional forest rights and uses, and indicate their needs for
basic socio-economic infrastructure such as classrooms, heath centers, water points and
roads. Weaknesses in the existing system, which include the need to better ensure
effective compensation and adequate representation of indigenous people, will be
addressed in the new Forest Code.




                                              43

121.      Enforcement of existing tax obligations, including the payment of community
fees, will help ensure the equitable use of natural resource wealth and will strengthen the
resource base of forestry communities. The audit of the fiscal system will also provide
further recommendations on the distribution of the revenue from the forest sector if
applicable and will shed light on any distortions, if any, to help the Government adopt
correction measures. The Bank, in collaboration with other development partners, will
support further analytical work on environmental management through a Country
Environmental Analysis (CEA) which is under preparation to help the Government
establish the regulatory, administrative, and technical capacity to identify, mitigate, and
monitor environmental issues in a sustainable manner.

                 C. IMPLEMENTATION, MONITORING, AND EVALUATION

122.      Implementation entity. The Ministry of Planning, Economics and International
Cooperation will be responsible for monitoring the reforms under the proposed operation,
as set out in the Letter of Policy Development, as well as for reporting progress and
coordinating actions among other concerned ministries and agencies. This ministry was
the unit responsible for coordination and implementation of the activities and reforms
under RIBSUP (DPO I).

123.      Program monitoring and evaluation. With a relatively weak national
monitoring system and a single tranche operation, the review and the goals of the
program will be largely based on relevant and easy-to-monitor indicators. Monitoring and
evaluation arrangements will rely on Government with the aim of strengthening
government capacity and institutions. CAR has designed a M&E architecture to follow
up on the PRSP implementation which covers the whole budget cycle, from planning to
execution. Building on this architecture, the EMGRG promotes a M&E institutional
framework for this operation's reforms and activities, for at least two key reasons: (i) to
ensure quality and timely information, and (ii) to start involving the civil society in the
accountability systems. In this regards, an implementation oversight committee, with the
mandate to monitor implementation of policies of the EMGRG is in place, with
representatives from all line ministries and directorates involved, as well representatives
from the regulatory agency in the petroleum sector.

124.      In parallel, collaborative monitoring has progressed among donors with the
government's support especially in public finance management, public sector and
economic governance, and all HIPC-related areas including public administration,
mining, forestry and transparency and the fight against corruption. The Bank and AfDB
have organized joint missions and AfDB will provide budget support in mid-2008 on the
basis of the same policy matrix that is presented in this document. The EC is also
considering aligning the policy matrix of its budget support with that of this operation.

                                  D. FIDUCIARY ASPECTS

125.      Although much remains to be done, in recent years PFM standards have
improved. Budget implementation and cash management are an objective which is at the
core of the operation. A Country Financial Accountability Assessment completed in



                                            44

FY08 helped assess fiduciary risks associated with budget support and deepened the
dialogue between donors and the Government on PFM issues. The CFAA developed a
joint donor-Government understanding of the main strengths and weaknesses of the PFM
system and has identified a list of prioritized recommendations based on the capacity of
the Government to implement these measures. This operation also takes into account the
results of a Treasury audit and the PEFA which are to be completed shortly. The
preliminary findings point to systematic underlying problems, as well as more punctual
shortcomings that are being addressed in this operation. The Bank will be engaged in a
very close dialogue with the Government to agree on necessary remedial actions that
insure integrity of public funds.

126.      The latest IMF safeguards assessment of the Bank of the Central African
States (BEAC), the regional central bank of which the CAR is a member, was made
in 2004. It found that BEAC had implemented a number of measures to strengthen its
safeguards framework since the 2001 assessment.

                                     E. DISBURSEMENT

127.      A single-tranche of SDR 4.8 million (US $7.9 million equivalent) will be
disbursed upon grant effectiveness. `The proposed grant will follow the Bank's
disbursement procedures for development policy operations. Once the operation is
approved by the Board and the Financing Agreement becomes effective, the proceeds of
the grant will be deposited by IDA in an account designated by the Recipient and
acceptable to the central bank , the Banque des Etats de l'Afrique Centrale (BEAC) at the
request of the Recipient. The Borrower shall ensure that upon deposit of the grant into
said account, an equivalent amount is credited in the Recipient's budget management
system, in a manner acceptable to the Bank. The Recipient will report to the Bank on the
amounts deposited in the foreign currency account and credited to the budget
management system. If the proceeds of the grant are used for ineligible purposes as
defined in the Financing Grant Agreement, IDA will require, promptly upon notice from
IDA, the Recipient to refund an amount equal to the amount of said payment to IDA.
Amounts refunded to the Bank upon such request shall be cancelled. The administration
of this grant will be the responsibility of the Ministry of Finance.

                              F. RISKS AND RISK MITIGATION

128.      The EMGRG has country, macroeconomic institutional capacity, and fiduciary
risks. These risks reflect the country's fragile security and political situation, as well as
risks associated with low government revenue and weak financial controls.

129.      Security risk. As in many conflict affected countries, deterioration in the
security situation constitutes an importance source of risk for the operation. In particular,
the deteriorating regional situation, whether in Sudan (Darfur) or in Chad would leave the
CAR at risk. A positive recent development has been the decision by the UN Security
Council in September 2007 to establish in Chad and the CAR, in concert with the EC, a
multidimensional presence intended to help create the security conditions conducive to a
voluntary, secure, and sustainable return of refugees and displaced persons. These



                                              45

security risks are exogenous and their mitigation falls largely outside the scope of the
operation.

130.      Political and sustainability risks. The recent history of political instability and
its post-conflict status leave the CAR also highly vulnerable to internal political
instability. The political situation remains fragile, as evidenced by the civil service strike
in January 2008, following the delay in paying civil servants salaries. The reform
program supported by the grant could falter as a result of policy reversals and slippages
or delays in key reforms, which could adversely affect the ability of the Government to
carry out poverty reducing priorities identified in the PRSP and undermine the
sustainability of the program. External resources by donors to some degree mitigate the
risks as they support sustained service delivery by Government. As further a mitigating
factor, the Government has expressed ownership and has demonstrated commitment to
reforms through the prior actions already carried out, and the definition of the follow on
measures. In this regard, the strong commitment to attain the HIPC Completion Point as
soon as possible also serves as an anchor of the reform program

131.      Macroeconomic risk. The country's macroeconomic performance represents a
risk. The success of the grant will depend critically on CAR's adherence to a medium-
term macroeconomic framework elaborated jointly with the Fund and the Bank. Risks
such as fiscal slippages, inability to stay current on wage bill payment and external debt
servicing, or a deterioration of the external environment, could weaken the operation.
These risks can be mitigated through a combination of fiscal prudence, a prerequisite of
the PRGF, and with inflows of donor funding. Close economic monitoring and policy by
the Fund, coupled with the Bank, can help guide the authorities on macroeconomic
management in the face of weak revenue mobilization, slow export growth, or terms of
trade shocks. The macroeconomic risk of falling back into arrears would be lowered as a
result of budget support from the Bank and other donors. Full debt-service payment to
IDA could be compromised if the CAR does not reach its HIPC Completion Point by
2009 and if aid flows remain insufficient or decline. To mitigate this risk, the Bank and
the Fund must continue to provide guidance to the Government and coordinate aid
support from the donor community.

132.      Vested interest risk. Benefiting from government instability, vested interests
have in the past exploited weaknesses in the governance framework and appropriated
natural resources to their advantage. This risk is reduced through strong up-front reform
measures in natural resource management and by tackling areas for reform with strong
vested economic interests (e.g. monopoly for petroleum imports). These areas are also
subject to a continuous policy dialogue under the HIPC process with technical assistance
from the donor community.

133.      Institutional capacity risk. A significant risk is weak institutional capacity and
delays that could arise from these capacity constraints. Despite achievements in terms of
building up capacity in CTPS-PAS, Ministry of Finance, and the Ministry of Planning,
Economics and International Cooperation, major constraints to the implementation of
reforms remain due to weak institutional capacity to prepare, implement, and oversee
reforms. Risk of limited implementation capacity is mitigated by (i) sustaining reforms



                                              46

that have started generating positive results and in which the country already has
developed stronger capacity such as in public finance management and governance; (ii)
concentrating on a limited number of themes/areas; (iii) ensuring that the most difficult
reforms are taken up-front; and (iv) donor harmonization which reduces the number of
activities to be implemented by the Government and help target efficiently the focus of
technical assistance. For this operation, technical assistance under the envisaged
Development Policy Operation, particularly assistance financed from LICUS Trust
Funds, with the additional funding from UNDP will help implement the reform program.
The Bank will coordinate with CAR's development partners to enhance synergy and
improve the efficiency of the DPO.

134.      Fiduciary risk. As the recently completed CFAA revealed, financial controls
in the CAR are weak although improvements in fiduciary standards has been a central
objective of the program and continued assistance in the areas of public finance
management under DPO I. The proposed EMGRG will continue to sustain improvement
in budget implementation. Since this operation is designed as a one-year stand-alone
operation, based on prior actions and subsequent follow on measures, IDA can adjust
subsequent operations to the pace of implementation and satisfactory usage of previous
grants by the Government.

135.      The foreign exchange system is under the control of the Bank of the
Central African States (BEAC), the regional central bank which manages the CFA
franc currency of Central Africa Francophone countries The latest IMF safeguards
assessment of BEAC, of which the CAR is a member, was made in 2004. It found that
BEAC had implemented a number of measures to strengthen its safeguards framework
since the 2001 assessment. These are improvement in the external audit process,
enhancement of the transparency of the financial statements, and strengthening of internal
audit function.




                                          47

                                Annex 1: Letter of Development Policy


                                Translated from the French Original



MINISTRY OF PLANNING, ECONOMY                               CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC
AND INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION                                       Unity-Dignity-Work



THE MINISTER OF STATE

No. _______/2008/MPECI                                      Bangui, April 14, 2008



Mr. Robert B. ZOELLICK
President of the World Bank Group
1818 H Street, NW
Washington, D.C. 20433
U.S.A.




Dear Mr. President,

        1.      I am honored to transmit to you the Letter of Development Policy from the
Government of the Central African Republic, in support of the request submitted to your
institution for a Grant in the amount of US$7.9 million.

        2.      The economic recovery begun in the past two years (2006-2007) thanks to the
reforms undertaken by the Government is still progressing, but at a slow pace. Considerable
attention has been paid to the management of public finances, but the results remain limited. The
economic and social environment, already fragile in this post-conflict recovery phase, is
suffering the effects of exogenous shocks such as the soaring price of oil and the depreciation of
the U.S. dollar. In light of these trends, fears of a resurgence of inflation are growing; this is
evidenced primarily by a steady rise in the prices of staples since the first half of 2007, and by
the shrinking purchasing power, already low, of the most underprivileged and vulnerable
segments of the population. The financial context is one in which the internal capacity to absorb
these shocks is extremely limited. The tax base is very small, and external resource mobilization
is insufficient compared with the development assistance received by other countries in post-
conflict situations. In these circumstances, the State cannot ensure the servicing of the debt with
a view to achieving the Heavily Indebted Poor Countries' Debt Initiative decision point or meet
the country's reconstruction needs, let alone undertake a support program for its least privileged
groups.

        3.      The Grant we are requesting, in the form of a second contribution to the program
of reengagement and strengthening of State institutions, is intended to help clear the way on two


                                                 48

fronts: i) Greater mobilization of assistance from the international community, and ii)
Consolidation of the capacity of State institutions to appropriately implement the economic and
social policy defined in the Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper (PRSP). At this time, the country
needs consistent support to start implementation of its PRSP in a context marked by economic
and social fragility.

       4.      Regarding the mobilization of international aid, the funds we request will help to
cover a part of our financing requirement for the second year of implementation of the program
supported by the Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility (PRGF). The second review of the
program, currently underway, is satisfactory. The Government's particular emphasis on
achieving the triggers serves as assurance that the Enhanced HIPC Initiative decision point, the
ultimate path to substantial easement of our debt-service obligations, will be reached as quickly
as possible.

       5.      As regards the strengthening of our institutions, the structural measures supported
by your Grant will focus on important points of governance, in particular the management of
public finances and natural resources, in order to best support the reconstruction of our country.
These measures will complement the progress already made, thanks especially to the World
Bank's assistance through the implementation of LICUS 1 and 2. Their execution will moreover
be facilitated by the increased mobilization of technical assistance for economic and financial
management institutions through LICUS 3, and by the support of the African Development
Bank, the European Union and France.

       6.      Your institution has noted that several prior measures have been taken; a large
part of the relevant documentation has already been submitted, and makes clear our
determination to grapple energetically with the challenges before us.

       7.      We venture to express the hope that examination of this dossier will prompt
favorable consideration by the World Bank Group.



                                             Yours sincerely,



                                     (sgd.) Sylvain MALIKO
