            LETTER OF DEVELOPMENT POLICY OF THE
             GOVERNMENT OF THE CENTRAL AFRICAN
                              REPUBLIC FOR 2008-2010


INTRODUCTION

8.      In the context of the reengagement of the international community, the Central African
Republic has benefited from the support of its main development partners; the latter have
demonstrated their solidarity by means of the clearing of multilateral arrears, agreement on a
program supported by the Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility (PRGF) over the period 2007-
2009 and the rescheduling of the debt owed to bilateral creditors who are members of the Paris
Club.

9.      The support of these donors has made it possible to finalize the Poverty Reduction
Strategy Paper (PRSP) for 2008-2010, the government's frame of reference for the
reconstruction of the country and the consolidation of sustained economic growth with a view to
effectively combating poverty. This paper is the expression of the Central African Republic's
will to undertake the reforms that are essential in setting itself on the path to development. It has
been prepared on a participatory basis, with the involvement of all strata of the national
population as well as domestic and foreign partners.

10.     In point of fact, the PRSP is based on four pillars: i) Restoration of security,
consolidation of peace and prevention of conflicts; ii) Promotion of good governance and of the
constitutional State; iii) Reconstruction and diversification of the economy, and iv) Development
of human capital by means of improved access for the people to basic social services, chiefly
education and health care, with a view to reducing infant, juvenile and maternal mortality, and
combating the HIV/AIDS pandemic.

11.     The program supported by the Poverty Reduction Facility agreed with the International
Monetary Fund forms a component of the implementation of the PRSP, and concentrates
essentially on improving the management of public finances in order to increase the credibility of
the budgetary policy. The satisfactory execution of the PRGF helped the country to reach, in
September 2007, the decision point of the Enhanced HIPC Initiative, thereby enabling the CAR
to benefit from interim relief of 90 percent of its multilateral debt service, with effect from
January 14, 2008. This relief will enable the CAR to ensure regular servicing of its debt, and also
to benefit from fresh concessionary lending by the development banks. In addition, we have
requested our official creditors to commit to maintaining positive net transfers so as to ensure
equitable treatment of all creditors together with the financial viability of the program.

12.     The second review of the PRGF, which has just been completed, is satisfactory and
demonstrates that the Government is committed to pursuing implementation of the reforms. The
results obtained confirm an upturn in the country's economic and financial situation. The
economy improved between 2006 and 2007, marked by the consolidation of social stability, the



                                                 52

progressive return of sustained economic growth and control of inflation. Real GDP grew from 4
percent in 2006 to 4.2 percent in 2007, while inflation fell from 6.6 percent in 2006 to 1.6
percent in 2007. This economic recovery, which gathered momentum in the past two years
thanks to the reforms undertaken by the Government, has also been reflected in a progressive
rehabilitation of public finances.

13.     Budgetary support for the government's program of reforms is provided in order to
deepen these reforms in specific fields, such as improvement of the management of public
finances and natural resources, together with other aspects of governance. In this connection
such support contributes to the improvement of governance (pillar ii) of the PRSP) and also
prepares the way for the diversification and growth of production (pillar iii) of the PRSP),
through provisions aimed at reassuring investors in the forestry and hydrocarbon sectors.

14.     In the fields selected, the priorities are to set appropriate foundations and strengthen the
State's capacity to pursue national reconstruction, while at the same time restoring confidence. In
order to send a strong signal, this restoration is based on the immediate adoption of a package of
measures, prior to the submission to the IDA board of the grant proposal which, if approved,
would result in the grant being disbursed in one single tranche.

MACROECONOMIC AND BUDGETARY FRAMEWORK

15.     The assumptions underlying the draft Finance Law for 2008 are based on the economic
prospects for 2008 and on the accomplishments noted at the performance midpoint of the 2007
budget.

16.     In 2008 economic prospects will depend on continued, resolute consolidation of
sociopolitical stability, including the progressive return of security to the interior of the country;
on macroeconomic stability, through the strengthening of economic operators' confidence,
recovery of raw materials prices, and stabilization of the price of oil; on pursuit of the reforms
undertaken by the Government with the support of its development partners; on commencement
of reconstruction of basic infrastructure; and on the consolidation of relations with the
international financial institutions following the Brussels Round Table of 2007.

17.     The orientation of economic policy toward poverty reduction and the consolidation of
sustained economic growth require, among other things, the sufficient mobilization of budgetary
resources. Implementation of this policy will make it possible to obtain an economic growth rate
of 4.8 percent in 2008, with an investment rate of 11.2 percent and a tax burden of 11.0 percent.
This level of growth would be sustained by the recovery of primary-sector activities, with a
growth of around 24.2 percent, due to the start of major works in 2008. The growth rate of the
tertiary sector would be 4 percent in 2008.

18.     In this context, GDP at current prices is estimated at CFAF 877.6 billion for 2008. This
level would be achieved thanks to: i) The support for cotton production, deriving from the
establishment of the new cotton company backed by financing from the French Development
Agency; ii) The heightened productivity of the forestry companies in conjunction with the
reassignment of old permits and the intensification of the activities of the SCAD, SEFCA and



                                                  53

SCAF companies; iii) The entry into operation of the AURAFRIC company; iv) The resumption
of major road-building projects (the road from Bouar to Garoua-Boulai; the rehabilitation of
Bangui's streets); v) The continued expansion of telephone coverage into the country's interior;
and vi) The ongoing reforms in the public-finances sphere.

19.     Regarding revenues, the forecasts of tax receipts for 2008 are based on those of 2006 and
2007 finance laws, coupled with spontaneous developments plus the implementation of a set of
administrative structural measures, all of which point to an estimated CFAF 98.5 billion in own
resources. To this must be added the external financial support received.

20.     The structural measures relate to the administration of the State corporations and
authorities (Régies). At the level of the Directorate General of Taxes, the efforts observed in
2006 and 2007 must be consolidated and improved through emphasis on the following: i)
Broadening of the tax base for VAT by eliminating the exemptions from VAT (with the
exception of transactions performed by agencies operating on external financing), making
taxpayers taxed at the minimum rate also liable for VAT and trading tax (patente) on the basis of
their turnover, and making VAT collection at source a general practice; ii) Intensification of
targeted checks including checks of stocks; iii) Reporting of leases believed to be fictitious, and
iv) Systematic verification of logging shipments to Douala (Cameroon).

21.     To the impact of these measures must also be added the effect on the tax base of the
economic activities referred to above: i) The establishment of the new cotton company thanks to
assistance from the French Development Agency; ii) The resumption of operations by
URAMINES-CAR and AURAFRIQUE; iii) The impact of regular payment of wages and
salaries on consumption; and iv) The expansion of forestry activities of the new companies.

22.     At the level of the Directorate General of Customs, the improvements will be apparent in:
i) The higher customs duties on timber; ii) The strengthening of the capacity of the Single
Window (Guichet Unique) in its role of ensuring the security of import flows; iii) The
strengthening of the border teams for tracking imports from the border into the interior of the
country; iv) The resumption of control at the container port; v) Continuation of the adoption and
utilization of the ASYCUDA++ computerized information system; vi) The encouragement of the
consequent resumption of river traffic; vii) Ongoing implementation of the reforms; viii) The
efficient application of the taxation of oil, which tends to neutralize the effect of the negative
TUPP on government revenues; ix) The upward adjustment of the rate of export duty for timber,
diamonds and gold nuggets; and x) The application of excise duty at customs points on wine in
bulk, ethyl alcohol and tobacco.

23.     With regard to the Directorate General of the Treasury, the Directorate of Collection and
Prosecution will consolidate the progress already achieved by means of: i) Broadening the
collection base in the ministries in order to improve collection of minor revenue items; ii)
Mobilizing counterpart funds to the Japanese grants for financing the expenditures of the Health,
Education and Agriculture sectors, and iii) Mobilizing funds deriving from the reassessment of
the telecommunications fee.




                                                54

24.     The contribution of external resources to investment expenditures has risen from CFAF
27.8 billion in 2007 to CFAF 31.4 billion in 2008; it is made up entirely of subsidies for capital
projects, in an amount of CFAF 31.4 billion. This increase in external financing is explained by
the carrying forward into 2008 of the large-scale road projects begun behind schedule in 2007,
and by the projects in the electricity and water sectors. Moreover the activities planned using
external financing are predominantly in the social sectors.

25.     As regards expenditure, government expenditures have risen by 10 percent compared
with 2007, going up from the CFAF 136.8 billion in 2007 to CFAF 150.9 billion. The rigidity
factors play a significant part here, specifically the requirement to meet community rules which
do not permit the budget deficit to exceed 3 percent of GDP. The context is not favorable for
achieving this objective in light of the volume of the debt service obligation, which remains
considerable (31.5 percent of own resources), and the new expenditure items to be covered.

THE GOVERNMENT'S PROGRAM OF REFORMS

26.     With the aim of consolidating economic growth and improving the social environment,
the Government will implement measures designed to improve the management of the public
finances and of governance.

Regarding budget performance and reporting

27.     To improve performance and reporting for the 2008 budget, which has been adopted
using the new budget nomenclature, the Government has put in place a new and efficient
procedure for managing public expenditure, and has appointed officials in the directorates
general with responsibility for the budget and public funds. It intends to follow through with
reporting by means of a quarterly report on budget performance (from commitment to
authorization of expenditures, in at least four key ministries: Infrastructure, Education, Health
and Agriculture), followed by submission of the 2008 Settlement Law to Parliament, which is
one of the fundamental objectives of the program. The strengthening operations envisaged by
LICUS III will make it possible to fully integrate the expenditures into the budget chain in order
to finalize an administrative account and proceed to the drafting of the 2008 Settlement Law.

28.     To strengthen the accounting system and improve the reporting of Treasury operations,
the Government immediately closed inactive and settled accounts held in commercial banks. It
has also finalized the new Treasury accounting nomenclature and posted treasury agents in all
departments generating minor receipts.

29.     In addition to the immediate closing of settled or inactive accounts, the reform program
proposes to audit accounts that are still active in commercial banks. These accounts will be
categorized according to their nature, closure dates and balances. In addition, an independent
audit will review these accounts and make a check audit of those showing deficits to be cleared
by the Government, all with a view to proposing a modality and a final action plan for closure
and rehabilitation of the government's accounts with the commercial banks.




                                                 55

30.     To enhance the State's credibility, we intend to prepare the government accounts for
2008, since this constitutes a vital step toward demonstrable transparency in the management of
public funds. Beyond the introduction of the new accounting nomenclature and the integration of
all the menus of the revenue-generating departments, the work to be done in order to fully
implement this measure consists of: (i) Integrating all the categories of accounts not covered in
the public accounts and which have been identified during the Treasury audit, and (ii) Adjusting
the new nomenclature to incorporate these accounts. Furthermore, the Government intends to
have the IGF perform an audit of internal debts for the years 2005 through 2007, so as to
establish an opening balance for 2008. The trust fund (LICUS III) includes modules to set up the
training courses needed, and to enable treasury agents to carry out this work.

Regarding revenue

31.     The Government is committed to improving its tax and customs administration. It has
accordingly decided to use ASYCUDA++ for issuance of certificates in respect of payment and
receipts for imports, brought in principally through the port of Douala in Cameroon.

32.     Customs revenues collected in the port of Douala after pre-clearance are paid into a
commercial bank in Douala, which then transfers them to the commercial banks in Bangui. This
reduces the amount of liquid funds available to the State, owing to the automatic fees charged by
the commercial banks in the offsetting procedures for collecting the State's debts; the
commercial banks also charge very high interest rates. The Government undertakes to transfer
the customs revenues to the BEAC, and to put into effect a strategy for reducing and
consolidating the debt to the commercial banks.

33.     With UNDP financing, the Government is currently completing an exhaustive survey of
taxpayers throughout the entire country. Basing itself on the findings of this survey, the budget
support program proposes to update the information in the Directorate of Taxes and Customs'
database and to bring the taxpayers thus identified under the current tax system. In order to
harmonize the data on foreign trade transactions and ensure their traceability, the program
proposes that a computerized link be established between the inspection company and the offices
administering taxes and customs. It is the government's intention that this activity be financed by
LICUS II.

Regarding improvement of the public sector and of governance

34.     To strengthen the formulation, coordination and monitoring of government policies to
combat corruption and to promote optimal natural resource management, we have established a
permanent and operational anti-corruption committee within the Prime Minister's office.

35.     The efforts to eliminate corruption will be intensified with the setting up of the above-
mentioned committee, which will be tasked with: (i) Designing a national anti-corruption
strategy; (ii) Drawing up an annual program of anti-corruption actions to be carried out by the
Government, and (iii) Production, publication and dissemination to the public-at-large of an
annual report detailing what the Government is doing in this field. The purpose of these
measures is to strengthen and coordinate the government's efforts and to increase transparency



                                                 56

and visibility in this key area. The make-up of the committee would include technical specialists
from the key ministries, together with representatives of employers and of civil society. The
members of the Government deposited their declarations of assets and liabilities with the
Constitutional Court in 2007, as required by Law 44 pertaining to the Constitution of December
24, 2004. However, since the law does not prescribe a standard format for the declaration, these
declarations have not been harmonized. Similarly, although the declarations have to be deposited
with the Constitutional Court 60 days before taking office, the law does not specify any penalty
for failure to do so. It would be important to strengthen the value of the declaration of assets and
liabilities by: (i) Fixing a standard format for it; (ii) Providing practical instructions for filling out
the declaration; and (iii) Setting penalties for delays or false statements, specifying the form and
content of the declaration, and any transitional or temporary requirements, among other things.
In this connection, it has been agreed with the Government that a presidential decree concerning
the declaration of assets and liabilities is necessary to strengthen this transparency measure. The
Government will be assisted by UNDP for the implementation of this measure.

36.      A strategy for procurement in the CAR was prepared in 2006 with technical assistance
from the World Bank. A revised draft code is ready and a legal expert has been hired to finalize
it. Another procurement expert from the African Development Bank will be working on the
practical application of the procurement strategy. Once the new code has been adopted by the
National Assembly, the next stages in bringing the reforms into operation will be: (i)
Appointment of the new members of the Directorate General of Procurement and of the
Regulatory Agency; (ii) Production of the manuals of procedures and determination of the
standard formats to be used; and (iii) Bringing into operation of the procurement units in the four
key ministries (Infrastructure, Education, Health and Agriculture) and production of an annual
report at the end of the fiscal year.

37.      The Ministry of Finance's website (http://www.finances-rcagouv.com) does not presently
include documents that have been uploaded to it, which lessens the value of the site. In an effort
to increase transparency and give greater visibility to the reforms of the State, it has been agreed
to increase the information available in the public domain by uploading the following
documents: (i) Mining and logging concessions; (ii) Treasury reports; (iii) Quarterly and annual
budget performance reports; (iv) Finance Law; (v) Annual reports of the Anti-Corruption
Committee; (vi) Anti-corruption strategy; (vii) New Procurement Codes, Forestry Code and
Mining Code; (viii) Constitution and United Nations Convention on Corruption; and (ix) Forms
and instructions for filling out the declaration of assets and liabilities. LICUS II will contribute
toward the financing of this measure.

38.      To strengthen governance in the forestry sector, the Government has produced a list of
companies that have failed to comply with the payment schedules for forestry taxes and has
suspended the granting of any new forestry permits until the new Forestry Code is promulgated.
The reason for these actions is that a review of the legal and regulatory requirements pertaining
to the forestry sector and of the situation of the companies holding logging licenses has revealed
that certain companies are not in good standing vis-à-vis the Government. Two particular
categories of cases have been noted: (i) Existing companies that are behind in paying the taxes
due to the State and have three months in which to pay these taxes if the State decides to grant a
moratorium, and (ii) New companies that have not met their fiscal obligations (equivalent to



                                                   57

three months' lease payments) within the time limit specified in the respective decrees (14 days
after promulgation of the decree). Current legislation stipulates that in the latter case the permits
must be withdrawn. We have proposed that these rules be strictly applied.

39.     Within the framework of the HIPC initiative, and with the aim of confirming the
objective of rational and sustainable management of forest resources, in 2006 the Government
undertook to review the Forestry Code in order to render the regulations more readable and
improve transparency and competition in the granting of logging permits. Nevertheless, some
permits have been granted following calls for bids put out in the course of 2007 on the basis of
decisions (arêtes) 003/MEFCPE/DIRCAB/DGEFCP/ DIAF of January and March 2007,
respectively.   The Government has suspended the granting of any new permits until the
promulgation of the new Forestry code.

40.     To improve governance in the downstream hydrocarbons sector, the Government has
enacted a law creating the new petroleum regulatory body and appointing the members of the
new agency responsible for regulating the structure of petroleum product prices.

41.     The regulatory agency's role is to regulate the oil and gas market in order to: (i) Control
the quality of the operators involved in the market by means of the criteria laid down in the
regulatory texts; (ii) Control product quality; (iii) Regulate competition in the oil and gas market
in the CAR, and (iv) Establish a price structure that is consistent with international prices and
permits the State to generate a level of revenue that is adequate in light of the sector's activities.
The budgetary support program suggests that for the agency to be effective its personnel should
be nominated in accordance with the established organizational chart and should perform the
functions assigned to them. A financing mechanism has been identified by the Government for
the agency's operation and the World Bank will offer technical assistance for strengthening its
capacity.

42.     In order to ensure the quality of petroleum products imported into the CAR we have
signed a contract with a firm of international repute to perform on-the-spot inspections and
controls of said products. The Government has committed itself to bringing the legislation
governing the downstream petroleum sector into conformity with international practice, in
accordance with terms satisfactory to the World Bank. To this end the World Bank will make
available to the Government the expertise that will enable accomplishment of this objective.

               RESULTS EXPECTED

43.     The results expected from this program, which we plan on extending over the medium
term, are in the first place better coordination and harmonization of the development partners'
actions around the government's main priorities, as described in the PRSP. We are also aiming at
a marked improvement in the management of public finances in all fields, not only in the
budgetary and accounting spheres but also as regards accountability. We attach particular
importance to improved management of public finances through sound performance of the 2008
budget and the preparation of a fundamental reform of the civil service, which we view as an
essential component of our program of economic and social reforms. Regarding governance, we
expect an improvement in the business climate, which should spur an increase in private



                                                  58

investment, both domestic and foreign, especially in the forestry sector which could become a
real axis of development in the future. Finally, as regards management of public resources ­ both
financial and natural ­ we are aiming at a significant improvement, in governance in general as
well as in transparency, particularly with regard to taxation.

CONSTITUTIONAL FRAMEWORK OF IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PROGRAM

44.     The program will be executed by the existing structures, which have demonstrated their
capability in the management of past programs --especially the two post-conflict programs
supported by the IMF. The CTP-PAS is a notable example. These programs are run by an
interministerial steering committee made up of the ministers involved in the implementation of
the program, including the Minister of State for Mines and Energy, the Minister of Water and
Forest Resources, the Minister of Justice, the Minister of Infrastructure, the Minister of Transport
and Civil Aviation, the Minister of Finance and the Budget, and the Minister of State for
Planning, Economy and International Cooperation, who serves as chairman. The Steering
Committee defines the strategic orientations of the works to be executed by the program's two
management structures, who report back to it periodically by means of reports detailing the
status of implementation of the program. These reports, once approved, are made available to the
donors, including the World Bank.

               CONCLUSION

45.     The Government of the Central African Republic takes this opportunity to reiterate its
commitment to efficient implementation of the program described in this Letter of Development
Policy, over the next three years. It is convinced that competent and satisfactory execution of this
program will contribute to the revival of the national economy, on a sound and sustainable basis
and with a view to reducing poverty. Against the backdrop of the reforms already undertaken,
and in light of the objectives fixed in this program and the results obtained during the course of
the program supported by the Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility (PRGF), which are most
encouraging, the Government of the CAR invites you to give favorable consideration to its
request of April 14, 2008, for a Grant of an amount equivalent to about US$7.9 million,
representing significant budgetary support for the financing of the implementation of the
reforms. We also hope to receive supplementary financing in the near future, through a
contribution by the AfDB that could be declared effective in June 2008. Finally, we very much
hope to reach the Enhanced HIPC Initiative completion point at the earliest possible date, since
our external debt is unsustainable.

Annex 4: HIPC Completion Point Triggers

                                Annex 5: Bank Activities in the Central African Republic


Name            Description



RIBSUP          US$82 million re-engagement budget support operation. US$75 million were used to pay arrears and debt servicing
(DPO I)         and US$7 million was used for budget support. The operation supported reforms in: (i) public finance management;
FY07            (ii) state-owned enterprises; (iii) governance; and (iv) natural resource management. On public finance management,
                (i) significant progress has been made on the expenditure front with tighter monitoring of cash advances, the
                creation of a line-item not exceeding 10 percent for unforeseen expenditures, the adoption of a decree for the reform
                of public expenditure procedures. However, the preparation of the new budget nomenclature is proceeding slowly,
                which compromises its readiness for the 2008 budget; (ii) with respect to revenue mobilization, the Treasury has
                been incorporating in the public account the amount of revenues captured by all line ministries and agencies at a
                percentage set by the Minister of Finance. The audit of the pre-clearance office in Douala (Guichet Unique) was
                completed. Based on the main recommendations of the report, the authorities are drafting an action plan that will
                form the basis of the main reforms underpinning the revamping of the Guichet Unique. The survey of tax payers at
                the national level will start in the last quarter of 2007, with financing from UNDP. Subsequent to this phase, the
                Bank will finance the registration of taxpayers in the SYSTEMIF and ASYCUDA systems of the tax and customs
                departments through LICUS II. LICUS II will also finance the reconciliation of the tax base between the customs
                and the BEAC to improve tracking and predictability of receipts. The state-owned enterprise component was
                delayed: settlement of the 2007 tax and utility bills between utility companies (electricity, water, and telephone) and
                the administration is hindered by lack of cash at the level of the Treasury, and poor management of cross-liabilities.

Multisectoral   US$17 million project approved in FY02 and restructured in FY07. The objectives of the Project are to assist the
HIV/AIDS        Recipient to contribute to: (a) urgent needs in the fight against HIV, such as access to prevention, treatment, and
Project         impact mitigation services; (b) urgent social needs, such as prevention of malaria, increased access to water supply
FY07            and improved primary education. The Project supports four key areas: (i) the National Program against HIV-AIDS
                Component; (ii) Support to Emergency Health Needs Component; (iii) Support to Emergency Needs in the
                Education Sector Component; and (iv) Support to Financial Management and Procurement.

Emergency       US$18 million investment project which aims to increase access to infrastructure and urban services in Bangui. The
Urban           project will rapidly rehabilitate, restore, improve and expand sustainable access to basic infrastructure services for
Infrastructure  the population of the most deprived districts of Bangui. The achievement of this objective would support GoCAR's
FY07            efforts to demonstrate visible and tangible improvements in the lives o f its citizens that are critical for sustaining
                social and political stability in the country.

CEMAC           US$201 million regional investment project including Cameroon CAR and Chad, part of a US $ 700 million donor
Transport       effort which aims to secure access to landlocked countries, enhance regional integration and increase trade in the
Transit         CEMAC countries. It consists of three sub-components: (i) roads and rail investment; (ii) investment in facilitation,
Facilitation    inter-modal platforms and port efficiency; and (iii) support to customs reforms and institutional support to policy
FY07            improvements.
                CAR Component of the project funded by IDA (US$ 24 million ) mainly consists of (i) a contribution to the paving
                of the Douala-Bangui link, as well as support to road maintenance, customs reform, and transport policy design

CEMAC Africa    US$45 million regional investment project which in the first phase will cover Cameroon, CAR and Chad. It aims to
Backbone        support population, businesses and Governments across the Central African region to have access to quality and
FY09            affordable ICT services by lowering the cost of international broadband capacity, and extending reach the of
                backbone networks. It is also expected to improve government efficiency and transparency through the development
                of eGovernment applications.

LICUS I         US$4 million Trust Fund. The overarching objectives of LICUS I was to recreate and strengthen the government's
FY04            technical capacity for public finance management and to support the provision of social and economic services to
                the population. The first phase of LICUS I provided immediate support for revenue collection and for reducing fraud
                and corruption in revenue administration. In a second phase, the grant further deepened PFM reforms, promoted
                governance and financial transparency and supported the provision of economic and social services with quick and
                visible impacts.

LICUS II        US$6.4 million Trust Fund. LICUS II built on the achievements of the first grant for public finance management and
FY07            governance and consists of four components: (i) Enhancing Governance and Economic Management Systems; (ii)
                Mining Sector Assessment; (iii) Community-Driven Development II Social Sectors; (iv) Interim Support to
                HIV/AIDS Treatment.



                                                                 78

LICUS III      US$2 million Trust Fund. The Enhancing Governance and Economic Management Systems (EGEMAS II) provides
FY08           technical assistance to deepen reforms in public administration and to enhance governance and the country business
               environment, especially with regard to oil and mining regulatory reform.

LICUS          US$2 million. The Social Service Delivery Grant secured short-term, just-in-time support to protect social service
Emergency      workers' salaries in the period March-April 2008 until further external resources can be realistically mobilized.
Operation
FY08

Poverty Report Preparation of a poverty report for CAR, based on urban and rural household surveys. The report provided
FY07           quantitative analysis as well as a review of available qualitative evidence on a range of topics: poverty profile and
               determinants of poverty, income sources, education and health services, basic infrastructure.

CFAFA          The CFAFA was finalized in October 2007. This report identified a series of deficiencies and shortcomings in the
FY07           CAR's public financial management and includes a global action plan of recommendations on the legal and
               institutional framework, budget and expenditures management, and customs and tax administration. A short-
               medium-term action plan has been discussed with the Government of the CAR, focusing on the following areas: (i)
               policy measures to strengthen budget formulation and preparation, budget execution and reporting; (ii) reforms to
               further rationalize treasury operations; and (iii) the capacity of the Government to mobilize revenue

CPIP           A CPIP was completed in April 2006, providing an assessment of the country's public procurement system and
FY07           proposes an action plan to improve and align procurement processes with internationally-recognized standards.22
               Actions recommended in the CPIP include the adoption of a new procurement code with regulations for standard
               bidding documents and guides, and the establishment of new procurement institutions. The EMGRG proposes to
               support the government's efforts to operationalize the new procurement procedures, notably the establishment of the
               Direction Général des Marchés and the Agence de Regulation and the decentralization of procurement processes to
               four key ministries, once the new procurement code is passed by the National Assembly. To assess the effectiveness
               of the government's efforts, this operation proposes the conduct of a post-procurement review.

DTIS           The report examines the constraints to regional and international trade integration. It identifies the dire situation of
FY08           the country's public finances as one of the significant problems that affects the country's competitiveness. Low
               levels of revenue and investment has led to a situation of poor infrastructure, which makes trade particularly
               difficult. The continued deterioration in the social sectors has likewise led to an erosion of the CAR's human capital.
               The EMGRG explicitly focuses on the need to improve the capacity of the Government to mobilize domestic
               revenue, through improved tax administration. Among the findings of the report which are relevant to this operation
               are those concerning the forestry sector. The DTIS recommends a thorough review of the pricing of permits, as
               current pricing does not reflect regional best practice. It welcomes recent efforts made by the Government to harvest
               resources in a more sustainable manner, as this will raise economic growth and poverty reduction in the medium-
               turn.

PEFA           The PEFA exercise is an integrated monitoring framework that allows measurement of the country PFM
FY08           performance over time. The information provided by this framework also contributes to the government reform
               process by determining which reforms are yielding improved performance and by increasing the ability to identify
               and learn from reform success. It acts as a framework for pinpointing strengths and weaknesses in financial
               accountability arrangements in the public sector, thereby helping the Government and donors to identify priorities
               for reform and supports both the exercise of the donors' fiduciary responsibilities and the achievement of broader
               development objectives.

DEMPA          The CAR is among the first countries selected for this debt management technical assistance (FY08), which aims to
FY08           strengthen capacity and institutions to manage government debt in an effective and sustainable manner, by assessing
               performance through a comprehensive set of performance indicators spanning the full range of government debt
               management functions, highlighting strengths and weaknesses. When finished, the DEMPA exercise (FY08), will
               provide a baseline of debt management performance indicators, on which the country's future debt management
               performance will be assessed. It will be a valuable tool in assisting the Government improves its debt management
               capacity, which is particularly important in a country which in the past has fallen into external debt arrears.




                                                                 79

                                 Annex 6: LICUS Trust Funds


1.      In general, implementation of activities funded by the first LICUS grant has been
satisfactory, albeit challenging. Major obstacles included: (i) the absence of government
services that could play the role of executing agencies; (ii) weak government capacity to
supervise activity implementation; and (iii) the low level of the Bank's presence in the
country. It was therefore decided to subcontract management to UNDP. Implementation
was initially very slow until 2005, following the assignment of a Bank resident economist
to Bangui. Results are reported below for each activity.

LICUS I

2.      Deterring corruption and tax evasion in revenue mobilization (US$159,500).
The objective of this activity was to increase revenue collection by reducing tax evasion
and corruption. The goal was to catch a number of corrupt individuals and give them
exemplary punishment, thereby deterring corruption practices. A unit (CEMIFI) was set
up to fight corruption and tax evasion and its members were nominated on October 22,
2004, and renewed thereafter. The LICUS grant financed communications equipment and
vehicles for the unit; the equipment was delivered in March 2005, while vehicles and
other equipment were delivered in July 2005. The unit is now operational and has been
reporting monthly to the Minister of Finance on progress on its task. The work of the unit
has contributed to government revenue collection, and on one occasion, it helped to
recover an amount of CFAF450 million, which could have been lost without its efforts.
Effectiveness of the unit is under assessment, and next steps will defined in agreement
with the Bank

3.      Capacity building in the Treasury department (US$68,000). On the basis of
reports of staff visits to treasury departments in Cameroon and Benin, the Minister of
Finance set up a government task team on budget and accounting reform. This team has
been instrumental in (i) the organization of a workshop in August 2005 on the status of
the budget and accounting reform, whose objective was to build consensus amongst civil
servants as to the need for and the principles of reform; and (ii) the preparation of new
laws on Public Finance, which have been presented to Parliament in 2006. Finally,
reports have been prepared on the reorganization of the treasury department and the
upgrading of the treasury accounting system that will help to strengthen public finance
management systems, notably as regards budget execution and cash management.

4.      Census of Domestic Arrears (US$70,000).             A consultant was recruited to
support the government commission set up to carry out a census of government domestic
arrears. The final report, prepared after full consultation with key stakeholders proposed
that the resolution of the domestic debt problem will require: (i) an exhaustive census of
the domestic debt, (ii) the verification and validation of the domestic debt and finally (iii)
the adoption of a clearance strategy. Subsequently, IDA and the Government have agreed
that the verification and validation of the stock of debt should be undertaken by a
competitively selected international auditor in line with international standards.



                                             80

5.      Control of government personnel and payroll (US$77,500). The objective was
to establish effective control over the number of civil servants and the payroll, which the
Government of CAR considered as a major and strategic reform. In support of the work
done with UNDP funding since 2001, LICUS resources were used to fund two
consultants, with the objective of setting up an integrated and computerized system for
civil service career and payroll management. An interim system has been operational
since January 2007. However, the completion of the above reform will need increased
financial resources, which were provided under LICUS II.

6.      Leadership seminars (US$252,380). Two seminars were organized in November
2004 and December 2005 respectively. The first seminar brought together leaders in the
political sphere and in the civil society and aimed at sensitizing them as to their
responsibilities in fostering a peaceful and nonviolent transition, with a view to seizing
the opportunities that would come from successful elections, notably the return of the
donor community to support the country in overcoming its financial crisis and in
addressing its development challenges. The key output was an agreed Code of conduct
that was endorsed and signed by major political leaders, which is seen as having been
instrumental in assuring the peaceful preparation and completion of delicate legislative
and presidential elections in March and May 2005. The December 2005 seminar targeted
the same category of participants, but focused on how to implement reforms through a
Rapid Results Initiative, in the areas of revenue collection and delivery of social services.

7.      PRSP finalization (US$964,940; Bank-executed): With the advent of newly-
elected institutions in March and May 2005, government priorities changed and the
dynamics of reengagement with the donor community gathered steam to the point that, in
July 2005, the CAR country team decided, together with the Government, that the
residual first LICUS allocation in an amount of US$718,640 should be used to fund
enhanced technical assistance to the country on PRSP finalization. Specifically, experts
have been hired to advise the Government in the following areas: (i) strategic planning,
monitoring and evaluation, (ii) macroeconomic analysis and programming, and (iii) the
PRSP participation process. These consultants began their assignments in May 2005, and
as a result, the pace of PRSP preparation substantially accelerated, particularly with
respect to participation and monitoring and evaluation. Furthermore, in addition to his
PRSP activities, the M&E advisor has been instrumental in helping the authorities to
prepare a multi-sector matrix which sets forth key policy actions to be undertaken over
the next 12-24 months. This matrix has served as the basis of the government's
Declaration of Economic and Social Policy that will underpin their request for
international support of arrears clearance and donor reengagement.

LICUS II

8.        Enhancing Governance and Economic Management system-EGEMAS
(US$2.7 million) and Mining Sector Assessment (US$450,000). LICUS II was
approved in October 2006, before the negotiation and approval of the DPO.
Implementation of the LICUS II has been slow in the beginning, because the Bank CAR
team and the CAR public administration staff were all totally absorbed by the
reengagement progress. The LICUS II grant was the first Bank project to be executed by



                                             81

a government unit, after country reengagement with the Bank. The Bank needed to build
capacity in the executing unit, before the latter could operate at performing level. The
learning curve and the technical capacity at the executing agency have reached a high
level so that the remaining activities are going to be implemented very rapidly. However,
LICUS II implementation had been accelerated during the second semester of 2007.
Currently several activities are under way or completed: (i) upgrading the government's
revenue collection system; (ii) capacity building in the treasury department to carry out
an audit of domestic arrears and design a clearance strategy; (iii) civil servant
management and payroll control to operationalize an integrated computerized system
between the Ministry of Public Administration and the Ministry of Finance; (iv)
improving the public procurement system; (v) mining sector assessment; (vi) review of
the tax and legal systems of the forestry sector; and (vii) building government technical
capacity to manage programs and projects..

LICUS Emergency Operation

9.        Social Service Delivery Grant (US$2,000,000). The main purpose of this grant
was to secure short-term, just-in-time support to protect social service workers' salaries
in the period March-April 2008 until further external resources could be realistically
mobilized. The immediate objective of the grant was to avoid a disruption of social
service delivery at this critical time. Non-payment of salaries as a result of other payment
obligations could have triggered internal unrest, broadened the civil service strike, and
hardened the position of unions regarding the payment schedule for past salary arrears as
pre-condition for resuming work.



Proposed LICUS III

Public Finance Management and Governance Support

10.       Enhance revenue collection (US$250,000). This component aims (i) to build
technical capacity in the tax department and (ii) to upgrade the management of the
taxpayers register. Implementation of these activities will build on the progress achieved
by prior efforts of rehabilitation of the tax and customs administration in the context of
LICUS I and II, and from other donors, and notably UNDP, the European Union and
France. LICUS I funded an initiative to deter corruption and tax evasion in revenue
mobilization, while LICUS II resources are being used to (i) to harmonize and establish a
link between customs (ASYCUDA) and tax (SYSTEMIF) databases, and (ii) to study the
import/exports tax base by reconciling Central Bank and Customs databases. Since the
transitional period, CAR has benefited from the support of the donor community in its
process to reform the tax and customs administration. In particular, the European Union
is currently providing a long-term support to CAR, notably aimed at revamping the
customs department. IDA, the IMF, UNDP and France have also provided support in
terms of diagnostic studies and short interventions to enhance revenue collection
institutions.




                                             82

11.       Improve budget preparation, execution and reporting (US$625,000). The
objective of this component is to provide sustained TA to the Ministry of Finance and the
Court of Accounts in order to enhance the management of public expenditures, as well as
the budget execution reporting. In the end, this should be reflected in: (i) the timely and
sound preparation of the budget law, (ii) an adequate monitoring and comprehensive
supervision of treasury operations; (iii) the preparation of budget execution reports; and
finally (iv) the timely review of government financial reports by the Court of accounts
and preparation of the budget execution law (loi de reglement), before its transmission to
the Parliament. The Bank's support of policy reforms in this area was designed in the
context of the DPO I, as well as at the occasion of the identification of HIPC completion
point triggers. The following reforms were initiated in the context of the DPO I: (i) the
audit of the treasury department operations for 2006, (ii) stringent monitoring of
government cash advances, (iii) integration of all government revenues, in the treasury
system, and finally (iv) the upgrading of the budget and accounting nomenclatures.
LICUS II resources were used in the implementation of the DPO I reforms and by end-
2007 progress was satisfactory, and the impact in the handling of the government
expenditures is positive. It is worth mentioning that the EMGRG aims to move forward
the above agenda to substantially revamp and upgrade the country public finance
management system.

12.       Public Administration Management reforms (US$350,000). Support from
UNDP and the Bank (with LICUS I resources) over the period 2001-2005 contributed in
carrying out a thorough diagnostic of the public administration sector. The component
objective is to support (i) the preparation of a new organic framework for civil service
based on the organizational audits which is consistent with PRSP objectives, and (ii) the
adoption of new rules and regulations for the civil servants, with compensation and
performance assessment systems. The new organic framework will build on
organizational audits which will be launched very soon under UNDP and LICUS II
funding, and will feature new employment nomenclatures, a new organizational set up as
well as required set of skills for each employment position. The new organic framework
will also encompass an integrated computerized system to manage the civil servants that
will have the following features (i) clear TORs for each employment position, (ii) an
adequate computer software, (iii) revised manuals of procedures, (iv) on-site training of
users, and (v) the commissioning of the new organic framework. The new rules and
regulations refer to the statute of civil servants, the remuneration scale, and the
management structure of the civil servants management.

13.       Reform and modernize the oil and energy sector (US$250,000). The
Government has recently launched a reform of the oil sector, aiming to ensure adequate
storage, distribution and pricing of petroleum products and to guarantee quality product
supplies as well as country strategic oil reserves. On the other hand, the oil business
should be a fiscal revenue source commensurate with the size of the activity and its
importance to the economy. In this context, the Government has enacted a new Law in
the first semester of 2007 that seeks to address most of the above-mentioned aspects. The
objectives of the government's reform are (i) to develop a stable market through open and
fair competition between operators by diversifying its supply base from procurement and
transport of product to handling, storage, and distribution; (ii) to generate a regular and


                                            83

steady stream of fiscal revenue to the State budget while ensuring supply at affordable
prices; and (iii) to secure the country's strategic reserve of petroleum products. In order
to reach these objectives, the Government intends to launch a range of structural reforms
as follows: (i) the strengthening of institutions involved in the management of the oil
sector, and primarily the staffing of the newly-created regulatory agency, (ii) the revision
and completion of the pricing structure in the oil sector; (iii) the revision of the sector
legislation. This LICUS III component will provide resources to fund the technical
assistance needed to carry out these reforms, building on earlier Bank support that helped
settle a dispute between the Government and Total, the only private firm operating in the
oil sector.

14.       Deepen reforms in the mining sector (US$500,000). The Bank has been at the
forefront in helping CAR improve governance and transparency standards in the
management of national resources, and in particular in the mining and forestry sectors,
through the LICUS II and the DPO program. The LICUS II funded an assessment of the
mining sector; in this context, an international firm was recently recruited and is currently
in the field to carry out a thorough assessment of the mining sector. The analysis will
provide a useful sector diagnostics and will help the Government, the donor community
and the private sector on how to promote and support business in this strategic area.
LICUS II will also fund consultation of stakeholders in the mining sectors so that they
can provide their input in the upgrading of the regulatory. The objective of this
component is to recruit experts that will help to design standard investment agreements in
the mining sector and to revise the mining code.

                                                                  85

                                 Annex 7: Fund Relations Note


           Central African Republic--Assessment Letter to the World Bank
                                       April 23, 2008

This IMF staff note assesses macroeconomic developments and prospects for the Central
African Republic based on information through the fourth quarter of 2007. The most
recent staff report on the first review under the PRGF arrangement was discussed by the
Fund's Executive Board on September 28, 2007 (Country Report No. 08/16, available at
http://www.imf.org). Program performance has continued to be satisfactory and
discussions for the second PRGF review were concluded, ad referendum, in March 2008.
The staff report supporting the authorities' request for completion of the second review is
being prepared and Board consideration is tentatively scheduled for June 13, 2008.

Recent developments

Performance under the current PRGF-supported program has been generally
satisfactory, taking account of the difficult external environment. Overall, the main
objectives of the authorities' program for 2007 were achieved, with a moderate increase
in economic growth, an improved revenue effort, and some progress in structural
policies. Regarding the fiscal accounts, the tax revenue-to-GDP ratio met the program
target and reached its highest level in a number of years (although it remains among the
lowest in developing countries). On the expenditure side, the authorities followed prudent
policies and the program target for the domestic primary fiscal surplus was met. Social
expenditures were in line with the program, but the performance criteria on wages and
commercial bank credit to the Government were not observed, the latter mainly due to
shortfalls in exceptional financing relative to program projections.

Most of the structural policy measures under the PRGF were implemented,
although some with a delay. These measures were directed at enhancing budget
management through improved revenue administration and public expenditure
management. The authorities are committed to implement an automatic petroleum price
adjustment mechanism (delayed structural performance criterion) to pass on changes in
world market prices and obtain higher revenues from petroleum taxation over the
medium term.

Outlook and program for 2008

The authorities' program aims to build a firm foundation for accelerating private
sector-led growth and alleviating poverty. In this regard, the main objectives are to
further consolidate the fiscal situation to reduce the overhang of debt and open room to
support growth-enhancing and poverty-reducing social policies. Raising the revenue-to-
GDP ratio is critical in this respect. Expanding the comprehensiveness of the budget, and
improving public financial and debt management are also important. The macroeconomic
anchor of the program is the domestic primary fiscal balance.




                                              86

In March 2008, the staff reached understandings, ad referendum, with the
authorities on the second review under the Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility
(PRGF). The objectives for 2008 are to achieve the following goals: real GDP growth of
5 percent to allow for continued progress toward reaching the Millennium Development
Goals; moderate inflation at less than 3 percent on average; further fiscal consolidation to
reduce the overhang of domestic debt and open room to support growth-enhancing and
poverty-reducing social policies; increase credit to the private sector; make external debt
more sustainable; and regularize relations with the remaining external creditors that have
not yet participated in the enhanced initiative for Heavily Indebted Poor Countries
(HIPC).

The program objectives aim at further fiscal consolidation in a difficult external
environment. The target for the domestic primary fiscal surplus is set at 0.3 percent of
GDP, which will require an increase in the domestic revenue-GDP ratio of ½ percent of
GDP to support the budget's expenditure program. An increase in domestic petroleum
product excises in June 2008 to generate additional revenues of 0.3 percent of GDP in
2008 is an important element toward reaching the revenue objective. The program
provides for a significant repayment of domestic expenditure arrears and a reduction in
expensive government borrowing from commercial banks.

Structural reforms aim at improving revenue administration and building capacity
in public financial and debt management. Program conditionality focuses on
increasing audits and enforcing collections; implementing a government financial
management information system; the introduction of a Treasury Single Account; and
enabling the debt management department to produce debt sustainability scenarios.

Major risks to the program are (i) shortfalls in revenues; (ii) difficulties in
implementing petroleum product price increases; and (iii) delays in and/or lower
volumes of foreign aid. Over the medium term, substantially higher aid inflows would
be needed to meet the authorities' goals for growth and poverty reduction. Also, given a
relatively weak administrative capacity, the smooth implementation of the program will
depend on well-coordinated technical assistance to build administrative and institutional
capacity.

Relations with the IMF

The Executive Board approved a Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility (PRGF)
arrangement in December 2006 with access equivalent to 65 percent of quota. The
PRGF arrangement is designed to support the authorities' efforts, as defined in their
Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper (PRSP), which was adopted by the Government on
June 30, 2007 after extensive consultations with the major stakeholders.



The authorities have requested an augmentation of access under the PRGF
arrangement equivalent to 15 percent of quota (SDR 8.3 million) to help adjust to
the external shock of higher oil prices. Executive Board consideration of the



                                            87

authorities' request for augmentation and the second review of the PRGF program is
conditional upon implementing the agreed automatic adjustment mechanism for
petroleum prices. Completion of the review will require waivers from the Executive
Board for the nonobservance of structural and quantitative performance criteria on the
basis of the corrective actions taken.

The C.A.R. reached the decision point under the enhanced HIPC initiative in
September 2007, and benefited from interim HIPC assistance from the Fund in the
amount of SDR 3.467 million starting in January 2008. The authorities are working on
implementing the triggers to reach the HIPC completion point.
